(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 29th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets pulling back this morning after a powerful rally yesterday. We're right down 70 points on the Dow Industrials right now, near the lows once again this morning. Nasdaq down 46 points. That's two-thirds of 1 percent, after a major rally in stocks yesterday. The Dow and the S&P 500 are now in positive territory for the month.

Stocks rallying 617 points on the Dow, 2.5 percent higher at the close yesterday. The S&P was up two and a third percent. The Nasdaq -- check that out -- 208 points higher, that's almost 3 percent higher.

Why the rally? These comments from Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: We know that moving too fast would risk shortening the expansion. We also know that moving too slowly, keeping interest rates too low for too long, could risk other distortions in the form of higher inflation or destabilizing financial imbalances.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Follow-through in Europe this morning. the FT 100 is up a half a percent, 33 points higher. The CAC 40 in Paris is up a half of a percent, 25 points higher. And the DAX index up 12 points, fractional gain there.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances -- take a look. Best performer was in Japan. Nikkei average up a third of a percent.

We are watching the price of oil today -- take a look. Crude oil fighting to hold a $50 a barrel level. It briefly fell below that for the first time in over a year just a few minutes ago. Oil now at $50.02 a barrel, down one-half of 1 percent.

Reining in big technology -- Facebook under fire after a new report says it was considering charging companies for user data.

Plus Google faces backlash for its project in China from its own employees.

All those stories coming up.

Facebook shares down another 1 percent his morning. Alphabet, parent of Google, down a half of a percent -- worries about regulation to come.

Ford Motor meanwhile is shifting gears. The automaker reworking its plans to ramp-up SUV and pickup truck production. It will not be cutting jobs.

A major change for Dick's Sporting Goods to report. The retailer considering removing all hunting gear from its store shelves.

And replacing Alexa with Big Mouth Billy Bass -- how you can get the talking fish to handle your usual Alexa request. Wait until you see this, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down -- Fox Business Networks' Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and Rosecliff CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy. Great to see you this morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning. Happy to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Great.

BARTIROMO: James -- I want to ask you about your op-ed that you wrote yesterday. The title was "Tax cut working better than advertised".

What I liked about this piece you wrote is you go into business spending. And why we haven't seen -- and we were talking about this yesterday, Dagen and me -- and why we haven't seen a bigger move in companies putting money to work. And I argued they are but it's in technology. We've moved from an industrial society to a technological society. So maybe the numbers don't tell the whole story.

FREEMAN: Well they do -- and they do tell part of the story. Obviously we've seen that increase in business investment this year. We've seen productivity going up which is good, allows for higher wages.

But, yes, that third quarter report on GDP it showed kind of softer than expected business investment. We kind of wondered why. Larry Lindsey, a former Bush advisor, says the time will -- hold on, I think maybe the investment numbers are going to get revised upwards. And that's just exactly what happened yesterday.

So better investment, more business spending on equipment, a lot of it technology to make employees more productive as we saw in yesterday's report.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It went from four-tenths of a percent increase to north of 3 percent, right, yesterday?

FREEMAN: Yes. So again, it's not the blowout of the first and second quarters but overall this year very strong and right on track with what the corporate tax rate cut enacted in December 2017 was intended to do -- increase investment in the United States.

MURPHY: And for those people who are saying it hasn't done enough, isn't it hard to go back and say where we would be without the tax cut or what the economy would look like without the tax cut?

FREEMAN: We saw it.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: We might look like Germany. Germany's economy is contracting, and so is Japan's. So we might not be in a recession. But if we hadn't had that tax cut, we would be -- well, we saw it during the Obama administration, is that what you were going to say that we never got 3 percent growth in any one calendar year.

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, as soon as the tax cut plan hit earlier this year when it first went into effect, we did see business spending shoot up. I mean, people -- businesses were reacting to that and then it slowed down, maybe the worry over tariffs.

FREEMAN: I think that is a concern, certainly. I think that's why we're looking -- if they get something resolved this weekend, I think you would expect some kind of market pop in response.

But the point is still very strong investment. Even if it's not quite at the pace of that initial burst right after the passage of the law, basically right on target and still in that 3 percent overall economic growth mode which was the point of the tax reform.

BARTIROMO: Check out James' op-ed in the "Journal" this morning.

Coming up this morning, joining this conversation, my exclusive interview with the chairman of UBS. Axel Weber is here. We will also speak with Calamos Investments CEO John Koudounis. We're talking about this market activity this year with John and Axel has a lot to stay in terms of the global story. Rock Group co-founder and Patron Spirits co-found John Paul Dejoria is here as well. Plus Wisconsin Congressman Sean Duffy. Also Senate-Elect Marsha Blackburn joining us as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off here with this top story -- turmoil for big tech. The "Wall Street Journal" reporting Facebook considered charging companies access for users' data. This is from internal e-mails viewed by the "Journal".

Facebook not the only technology company facing trouble and potential regulation. Google is facing employee backlash over its project Dragonfly which would be a censored search engine for China. Really interesting to note that Google walked away from doing business with the Pentagon and instead chose to do business with China where they have to censor their search engine.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Tennessee Congresswoman and Senator-Elect Marsha Blackburn. Senator-Elect -- congratulations to you. Good to see you.

SENATOR-ELECT MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNESSEE: Thank you, Maria. Nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. You've been working a lot on this potential, I don't know if you want to call it regulatory response or what is the response to this in terms of technology? What do you want to see happen within big tech?

BLACKBURN: What I would like to see happen is passage of the Browser Act which is privacy regulations. It puts one -- one template in place for the entire ecosystem, whether it is your Internet service provider, which is your ISP or it is one of the edge providers which is Facebook, Google, Twitter, those companies, big tech.

And Maria -- they have resisted this. What they wanted was to put all of the privacy regulation on the ISPs. That would have been the 2015 rules that the Obama administration had wanted to put in place. But it needs to be one set of rules for the ecosystem.

And then you get into issues past that and the privacy regulations, you get into the other issues which have to do with the operating systems, which is the Google operating system which you can turn the thing off, pull the sim card, these devices still are tracking you. And yes, that is an invasion of your privacy.

BARTIROMO: So is that the big issue? Characterize what the problem is around big tech. They're tracking us all the time and we don't know it.

BLACKBURN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: But there's also an issue that you and your colleagues have pointed out about censoring conservative conversation.

BLACKBURN: That is right. And those are two separate issues.

Now when it comes to privacy, here is what we need to do. We need to make certain that the consumer, the individual that is looking at that computer screen and conducting much of their transactional life online, that they have the ability to say to these different systems, whether it is Google or Facebook or whomever on the edge, no, you do not have access to my sensitive data and I have the right to block you from using that.

And when it comes to non-sensitive data, like your search history that you can say I am opting out and reserving to myself the individual the right to protect my virtual self online; and you, big tech, cannot use my search data and then turn around and sell that to an advertiser or somebody.

FREEMAN: Senator-Elect -- James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal".

BLACKBURN: Yes.

FREEMAN: I hate to raise a discouraging word, because I don't know many people who are more excited about your election than I am. I'm not going to knock your predecessor at this moment, but in this particular issue, do you worry about creating a new Internet regulator in Washington? Do you worry about big companies like Facebook benefiting from heavy regulation more than their potential competitors will, who may have a tougher time complying with this kind of regulation?

BLACKBURN: Yes. Not at all -- James. That is why I think it's important that we do light touch privacy standards and put that in place.

And we have a privacy regulator in the marketplace now. It's called the Federal Trade Commission, the FTC. And having that light touch regulation in place where they are able to say, ok, the individual reserves their privacy. It is the same thing that has happened in the physical space, if you will.

And for decades, different retailers and merchants and individuals you conduct transactions with have had affinity programs, loyalty programs. And what you want to do is replicate that in the virtual space and allow the individual to decide what information they want to share and what they want to hold private.

As it is right now, big tech can just run roughshod if you will over your transactional life online and they are scooping this information. When you look at things like the Science Project and you see that these Google operating systems will track every single base station that you pass, even with the phone deactivated, if you will.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So you don't know who to trust. You've got the technology companies tracking us. You've got China tracking us.

I've got to get your take on this breaking news this morning. And this comes from Reuters, Senator-Elect Blackburn. The Trump administration reportedly considering checking Chinese students' phone records and social media accounts for anything that may raise concerns about why they are in the United States. Your reaction to this report?

And it only comes a couple days after we know that there was another report that showed us that China is judging everybody -- the 1.4 billion people there -- and coming up with a national score, an individual score, rather, for each person. And that's going to dictate whether you can get a mortgage, whether you can get on a train or a plane.

So should the U.S. be spying on Chinese citizens to make sure they're here for the right reasons?

BLACKBURN: Well, let me say this about China. We have been concerned about the way they interact with U.S. companies for many, many, many years. And when it comes to dealing with them, I've not seen the report that you're referencing but I will say this. I think that Secretary Pompeo is doing a really quite remarkable job handling and working on the world stage and making certain that we make wise decisions in our interactions with other countries. And so I look forward to seeing what he has to say about this.

BARTIROMO: So you're going to keep the pressure on big tech.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What else are your priorities once you begin your term in the Senate?

I mean the President tweeted on the Mueller probe this morning, I'd like to know what you think about that. Here's what the President said just a little while ago. "Did you ever see an investigation more in search of a crime? At the same time Mueller and the angry Democrats aren't even looking at the atrocious and perhaps subversive crimes that were committed by Crooked Hillary Clinton and the Democrats. A total disgrace."

This of course, as Senate Republicans blocked legislation yesterday that would protect special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Was that the right move? Tell us where you are on the Mueller investigation and what you're going to do once you get there in the Senate.

BLACKBURN: I'll tell you, Maria -- when I was campaigning across the state in Tennessee, and something would be said about the Mueller investigation, Tennesseans would say this thing needs to get wrapped up. This thing needs to get finished. And Tennesseans are really not, you know, they're not that concerned about the story of the day, if you will.

What they are concerned about is the story of their lives and they are absolutely so pleased with what they see as consistent growth. And I was listening to the conversation --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: -- relative to that. They like the fact that the economy is growing. Things are better for their family.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: They are looking forward to having a good Christmas and just really rocking it in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Well, like I said yesterday, it's time.

BLACKBURN: It's time.

BARTIROMO: Let's see what you've got, Robert Mueller. It's been two years. We'll see if you and your colleagues will see that report early in the new year.

Good to see you. Marsha Blackburn -- thanks very much for your insights this morning.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you.

Coming up, Ford is shifting gears -- the automaker reworking its plants to ramp-up SUV and pickup truck production. It will not cutting jobs while doing so.

Then a change for Dick's Sporting Goods, the controversial decision by the athletic retailer to potentially get rid of virtually all of its hunting gear.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Futures are lower this morning, well off of the lows of the morning though. Dow Industrials now looking down about 30 points, S&P down 6, down 30 points on the Nasdaq as well.

Do you think it's good news, Mike Murphy, if we see follow-through to a 600-point rally yesterday or is it bad news? Sometimes people want to make sure that you see that the selling is done before coming in. You want to see --

MURPHY: We had a 10 percent correction. We had a lot of selling come into the market. We had a very positive announcement from the Fed yesterday. We had a big rally. I want more of the rally. And if we get anything out of the G-20 this weekend, yesterday's rally will be tame in what happens Monday and Tuesday.

BARTIROMO: So does that tell you anything about what happens the rest of the year if in fact we see buying follow-through this morning? Even though markets are lower right now.

MURPHY: It does. I mean the way I look at it is that we sold off for one of the main reasons was the trade war, the tariffs and the effect that could have. And if you take that off the table, we go back to where we were in the markets.

MCDOWELL: The steel and aluminum tariffs are not going away. And when President Trump is tweeting about import tariffs on small cars to match what we already do on light trucks, I don't think that this tariff issue is going away any time soon.

MURPHY: But that's part of the China issue, right. If that gets resolved.

MCDOWELL: They say, but it's not. It's to save the steel industry in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Markets are lower this morning, down as you can see. We'll keep watching that.

Meanwhile there's this. Ford Motor moving around some of its U.S. workers to meet the growing demand for pickups and SUVs.

Cheryl Casone on that now and headlines -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes -- Maria.

The change is going to affect more than 1,100 workers but no jobs are going to be cut in this one. Ford added it's confident it's going to be able to find new jobs for 150 other workers at a Michigan plant.

Now this is just days after General Motors said its' cutting nearly 15,000 jobs and closing five factories in North America.

Ford shares are down 25 percent this year while GM shares are down 10 percent. So some pressure on these stocks for the year.

I want to stay on cars. Amazon is getting into the toy car business. This is Amazon's new self-driving toy car. It's called the AWS DeepRacer. You can program the car to drive itself. It uses A.I. to learn to drive better through trial and error.

It's also launching a racing league of these cars to put customers' programming skills to the test. That's $400, by the way, when it comes out next year if you're willing to spend that on a toy car. It's available to preorder now for a special price of $249 -- Maria. Sending it back to the group that has kids because I don't know. It's expensive.

BARTIROMO: Thank you -- Cheryl.

MURPHY: Do you ride in the car or is it you just control the car?

CASONE: You just control it.

MURPHY: Ok.

FREEMAN: Does the car record everything going on in the household and then send that back --

BARTIROMO: Of course.

FREEMAN: -- to Amazon while it's moving around the living room? Or does it just drive I think would be one natural question.

BARTIROMO: It comes like -- I'm betting that they're recording us at all times.

Meanwhile President Trump just tweeted on the Mueller probe again. Here's what he said. "When will this illegal Joseph McCarthy style witch hunt, one that has shattered so many innocent lives ever end or will it just go on forever. After wasting more than $40 million (is that possible), it has proven only one thing -- there was no collusion with Russia. So ridiculous." The President writes this morning.

We're looking at real estate realities next, the outlook on housing. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New concerns about the health of the housing market. October new home sales sliding to the lowest level in more than two and-a-half years. It is the latest sign that rising interest rates are hitting the market.

Joining us now is Rogers Healy and Associates real estate owner and CEO, Rogers Healy. Good to see you Rogers. Thanks very much for joining us.

Are we seeing a slowdown --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGERS HEALY, CEO, ROGERS HEALY AND ASSOCIATES: Good morning. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: -- in housing and tell us how severe it is.

HEALY: It's not severe. I mean first of all, what we do is seasonal, right. Especially in residential, it is seasonal. And so this time of year we do see a slowdown. But obviously the last two years, really the last four or five years it's been really, really, really, really, really, really busy and really, really good.

But it has slowed down a little bit. And for interest rates to get closer to 5 percent, it's more expensive for the house the person thought they could afford. Now they really can't. So, you know, that has definitely slowed us down but the market is still fine.

MCDOWELL: Rogers -- sorry, Mike. Rogers -- you're in Texas.

HEALY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Are you worried about the impact on the major drop in oil prices on the Texas economy and on your business?

HEALY: You said do I worry about it?

MCDOWELL: Yes. urn:contentItem:5TWG-6RM1-JBHT-D064-00000-00Reining in Big Tech; Ford Shifts Gears; Amazon's Self-Driving Toy Car; Outlook on Housing; UBS Chairman on Deutsche Bank Money Laundering Probe Raids; Altria in Talks with Juul; ROKiT to Release its First Glasses- Free, Naked Eye 3D Phone2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:50ZLexisNexisReining in Big Tech; Ford Shifts Gears; Amazon's Self-Driving Toy Car; Outlook on Housing; UBS Chairman on Deutsche Bank Money Laundering Probe Raids; Altria in Talks with Juul; ROKiT to Release its First Glasses- Free, Naked Eye 3D PhoneLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 29th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets pulling back this morning after a powerful rally yesterday. We're right down 70 points on the Dow Industrials right now, near the lows once again this morning. Nasdaq down 46 points. That's two-thirds of 1 percent, after a major rally in stocks yesterday. The Dow and the S&P 500 are now in positive territory for the month.

Stocks rallying 617 points on the Dow, 2.5 percent higher at the close yesterday. The S&P was up two and a third percent. The Nasdaq -- check that out -- 208 points higher, that's almost 3 percent higher.

Why the rally? These comments from Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: We know that moving too fast would risk shortening the expansion. We also know that moving too slowly, keeping interest rates too low for too long, could risk other distortions in the form of higher inflation or destabilizing financial imbalances.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Follow-through in Europe this morning. the FT 100 is up a half a percent, 33 points higher. The CAC 40 in Paris is up a half of a percent, 25 points higher. And the DAX index up 12 points, fractional gain there.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances -- take a look. Best performer was in Japan. Nikkei average up a third of a percent.

We are watching the price of oil today -- take a look. Crude oil fighting to hold a $50 a barrel level. It briefly fell below that for the first time in over a year just a few minutes ago. Oil now at $50.02 a barrel, down one-half of 1 percent.

Reining in big technology -- Facebook under fire after a new report says it was considering charging companies for user data.

Plus Google faces backlash for its project in China from its own employees.

All those stories coming up.

Facebook shares down another 1 percent his morning. Alphabet, parent of Google, down a half of a percent -- worries about regulation to come.

Ford Motor meanwhile is shifting gears. The automaker reworking its plans to ramp-up SUV and pickup truck production. It will not be cutting jobs.

A major change for Dick's Sporting Goods to report. The retailer considering removing all hunting gear from its store shelves.

And replacing Alexa with Big Mouth Billy Bass -- how you can get the talking fish to handle your usual Alexa request. Wait until you see this, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down -- Fox Business Networks' Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and Rosecliff CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy. Great to see you this morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning. Happy to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Great.

BARTIROMO: James -- I want to ask you about your op-ed that you wrote yesterday. The title was "Tax cut working better than advertised".

What I liked about this piece you wrote is you go into business spending. And why we haven't seen -- and we were talking about this yesterday, Dagen and me -- and why we haven't seen a bigger move in companies putting money to work. And I argued they are but it's in technology. We've moved from an industrial society to a technological society. So maybe the numbers don't tell the whole story.

FREEMAN: Well they do -- and they do tell part of the story. Obviously we've seen that increase in business investment this year. We've seen productivity going up which is good, allows for higher wages.

But, yes, that third quarter report on GDP it showed kind of softer than expected business investment. We kind of wondered why. Larry Lindsey, a former Bush advisor, says the time will -- hold on, I think maybe the investment numbers are going to get revised upwards. And that's just exactly what happened yesterday.

So better investment, more business spending on equipment, a lot of it technology to make employees more productive as we saw in yesterday's report.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It went from four-tenths of a percent increase to north of 3 percent, right, yesterday?

FREEMAN: Yes. So again, it's not the blowout of the first and second quarters but overall this year very strong and right on track with what the corporate tax rate cut enacted in December 2017 was intended to do -- increase investment in the United States.

MURPHY: And for those people who are saying it hasn't done enough, isn't it hard to go back and say where we would be without the tax cut or what the economy would look like without the tax cut?

FREEMAN: We saw it.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: We might look like Germany. Germany's economy is contracting, and so is Japan's. So we might not be in a recession. But if we hadn't had that tax cut, we would be -- well, we saw it during the Obama administration, is that what you were going to say that we never got 3 percent growth in any one calendar year.

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, as soon as the tax cut plan hit earlier this year when it first went into effect, we did see business spending shoot up. I mean, people -- businesses were reacting to that and then it slowed down, maybe the worry over tariffs.

FREEMAN: I think that is a concern, certainly. I think that's why we're looking -- if they get something resolved this weekend, I think you would expect some kind of market pop in response.

But the point is still very strong investment. Even if it's not quite at the pace of that initial burst right after the passage of the law, basically right on target and still in that 3 percent overall economic growth mode which was the point of the tax reform.

BARTIROMO: Check out James' op-ed in the "Journal" this morning.

Coming up this morning, joining this conversation, my exclusive interview with the chairman of UBS. Axel Weber is here. We will also speak with Calamos Investments CEO John Koudounis. We're talking about this market activity this year with John and Axel has a lot to stay in terms of the global story. Rock Group co-founder and Patron Spirits co-found John Paul Dejoria is here as well. Plus Wisconsin Congressman Sean Duffy. Also Senate-Elect Marsha Blackburn joining us as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off here with this top story -- turmoil for big tech. The "Wall Street Journal" reporting Facebook considered charging companies access for users' data. This is from internal e-mails viewed by the "Journal".

Facebook not the only technology company facing trouble and potential regulation. Google is facing employee backlash over its project Dragonfly which would be a censored search engine for China. Really interesting to note that Google walked away from doing business with the Pentagon and instead chose to do business with China where they have to censor their search engine.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Tennessee Congresswoman and Senator-Elect Marsha Blackburn. Senator-Elect -- congratulations to you. Good to see you.

SENATOR-ELECT MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNESSEE: Thank you, Maria. Nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. You've been working a lot on this potential, I don't know if you want to call it regulatory response or what is the response to this in terms of technology? What do you want to see happen within big tech?

BLACKBURN: What I would like to see happen is passage of the Browser Act which is privacy regulations. It puts one -- one template in place for the entire ecosystem, whether it is your Internet service provider, which is your ISP or it is one of the edge providers which is Facebook, Google, Twitter, those companies, big tech.

And Maria -- they have resisted this. What they wanted was to put all of the privacy regulation on the ISPs. That would have been the 2015 rules that the Obama administration had wanted to put in place. But it needs to be one set of rules for the ecosystem.

And then you get into issues past that and the privacy regulations, you get into the other issues which have to do with the operating systems, which is the Google operating system which you can turn the thing off, pull the sim card, these devices still are tracking you. And yes, that is an invasion of your privacy.

BARTIROMO: So is that the big issue? Characterize what the problem is around big tech. They're tracking us all the time and we don't know it.

BLACKBURN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: But there's also an issue that you and your colleagues have pointed out about censoring conservative conversation.

BLACKBURN: That is right. And those are two separate issues.

Now when it comes to privacy, here is what we need to do. We need to make certain that the consumer, the individual that is looking at that computer screen and conducting much of their transactional life online, that they have the ability to say to these different systems, whether it is Google or Facebook or whomever on the edge, no, you do not have access to my sensitive data and I have the right to block you from using that.

And when it comes to non-sensitive data, like your search history that you can say I am opting out and reserving to myself the individual the right to protect my virtual self online; and you, big tech, cannot use my search data and then turn around and sell that to an advertiser or somebody.

FREEMAN: Senator-Elect -- James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal".

BLACKBURN: Yes.

FREEMAN: I hate to raise a discouraging word, because I don't know many people who are more excited about your election than I am. I'm not going to knock your predecessor at this moment, but in this particular issue, do you worry about creating a new Internet regulator in Washington? Do you worry about big companies like Facebook benefiting from heavy regulation more than their potential competitors will, who may have a tougher time complying with this kind of regulation?

BLACKBURN: Yes. Not at all -- James. That is why I think it's important that we do light touch privacy standards and put that in place.

And we have a privacy regulator in the marketplace now. It's called the Federal Trade Commission, the FTC. And having that light touch regulation in place where they are able to say, ok, the individual reserves their privacy. It is the same thing that has happened in the physical space, if you will.

And for decades, different retailers and merchants and individuals you conduct transactions with have had affinity programs, loyalty programs. And what you want to do is replicate that in the virtual space and allow the individual to decide what information they want to share and what they want to hold private.

As it is right now, big tech can just run roughshod if you will over your transactional life online and they are scooping this information. When you look at things like the Science Project and you see that these Google operating systems will track every single base station that you pass, even with the phone deactivated, if you will.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So you don't know who to trust. You've got the technology companies tracking us. You've got China tracking us.

I've got to get your take on this breaking news this morning. And this comes from Reuters, Senator-Elect Blackburn. The Trump administration reportedly considering checking Chinese students' phone records and social media accounts for anything that may raise concerns about why they are in the United States. Your reaction to this report?

And it only comes a couple days after we know that there was another report that showed us that China is judging everybody -- the 1.4 billion people there -- and coming up with a national score, an individual score, rather, for each person. And that's going to dictate whether you can get a mortgage, whether you can get on a train or a plane.

So should the U.S. be spying on Chinese citizens to make sure they're here for the right reasons?

BLACKBURN: Well, let me say this about China. We have been concerned about the way they interact with U.S. companies for many, many, many years. And when it comes to dealing with them, I've not seen the report that you're referencing but I will say this. I think that Secretary Pompeo is doing a really quite remarkable job handling and working on the world stage and making certain that we make wise decisions in our interactions with other countries. And so I look forward to seeing what he has to say about this.

BARTIROMO: So you're going to keep the pressure on big tech.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What else are your priorities once you begin your term in the Senate?

I mean the President tweeted on the Mueller probe this morning, I'd like to know what you think about that. Here's what the President said just a little while ago. "Did you ever see an investigation more in search of a crime? At the same time Mueller and the angry Democrats aren't even looking at the atrocious and perhaps subversive crimes that were committed by Crooked Hillary Clinton and the Democrats. A total disgrace."

This of course, as Senate Republicans blocked legislation yesterday that would protect special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Was that the right move? Tell us where you are on the Mueller investigation and what you're going to do once you get there in the Senate.

BLACKBURN: I'll tell you, Maria -- when I was campaigning across the state in Tennessee, and something would be said about the Mueller investigation, Tennesseans would say this thing needs to get wrapped up. This thing needs to get finished. And Tennesseans are really not, you know, they're not that concerned about the story of the day, if you will.

What they are concerned about is the story of their lives and they are absolutely so pleased with what they see as consistent growth. And I was listening to the conversation --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: -- relative to that. They like the fact that the economy is growing. Things are better for their family.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: They are looking forward to having a good Christmas and just really rocking it in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Well, like I said yesterday, it's time.

BLACKBURN: It's time.

BARTIROMO: Let's see what you've got, Robert Mueller. It's been two years. We'll see if you and your colleagues will see that report early in the new year.

Good to see you. Marsha Blackburn -- thanks very much for your insights this morning.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you.

Coming up, Ford is shifting gears -- the automaker reworking its plants to ramp-up SUV and pickup truck production. It will not cutting jobs while doing so.

Then a change for Dick's Sporting Goods, the controversial decision by the athletic retailer to potentially get rid of virtually all of its hunting gear.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Futures are lower this morning, well off of the lows of the morning though. Dow Industrials now looking down about 30 points, S&P down 6, down 30 points on the Nasdaq as well.

Do you think it's good news, Mike Murphy, if we see follow-through to a 600-point rally yesterday or is it bad news? Sometimes people want to make sure that you see that the selling is done before coming in. You want to see --

MURPHY: We had a 10 percent correction. We had a lot of selling come into the market. We had a very positive announcement from the Fed yesterday. We had a big rally. I want more of the rally. And if we get anything out of the G-20 this weekend, yesterday's rally will be tame in what happens Monday and Tuesday.

BARTIROMO: So does that tell you anything about what happens the rest of the year if in fact we see buying follow-through this morning? Even though markets are lower right now.

MURPHY: It does. I mean the way I look at it is that we sold off for one of the main reasons was the trade war, the tariffs and the effect that could have. And if you take that off the table, we go back to where we were in the markets.

MCDOWELL: The steel and aluminum tariffs are not going away. And when President Trump is tweeting about import tariffs on small cars to match what we already do on light trucks, I don't think that this tariff issue is going away any time soon.

MURPHY: But that's part of the China issue, right. If that gets resolved.

MCDOWELL: They say, but it's not. It's to save the steel industry in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Markets are lower this morning, down as you can see. We'll keep watching that.

Meanwhile there's this. Ford Motor moving around some of its U.S. workers to meet the growing demand for pickups and SUVs.

Cheryl Casone on that now and headlines -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes -- Maria.

The change is going to affect more than 1,100 workers but no jobs are going to be cut in this one. Ford added it's confident it's going to be able to find new jobs for 150 other workers at a Michigan plant.

Now this is just days after General Motors said its' cutting nearly 15,000 jobs and closing five factories in North America.

Ford shares are down 25 percent this year while GM shares are down 10 percent. So some pressure on these stocks for the year.

I want to stay on cars. Amazon is getting into the toy car business. This is Amazon's new self-driving toy car. It's called the AWS DeepRacer. You can program the car to drive itself. It uses A.I. to learn to drive better through trial and error.

It's also launching a racing league of these cars to put customers' programming skills to the test. That's $400, by the way, when it comes out next year if you're willing to spend that on a toy car. It's available to preorder now for a special price of $249 -- Maria. Sending it back to the group that has kids because I don't know. It's expensive.

BARTIROMO: Thank you -- Cheryl.

MURPHY: Do you ride in the car or is it you just control the car?

CASONE: You just control it.

MURPHY: Ok.

FREEMAN: Does the car record everything going on in the household and then send that back --

BARTIROMO: Of course.

FREEMAN: -- to Amazon while it's moving around the living room? Or does it just drive I think would be one natural question.

BARTIROMO: It comes like -- I'm betting that they're recording us at all times.

Meanwhile President Trump just tweeted on the Mueller probe again. Here's what he said. "When will this illegal Joseph McCarthy style witch hunt, one that has shattered so many innocent lives ever end or will it just go on forever. After wasting more than $40 million (is that possible), it has proven only one thing -- there was no collusion with Russia. So ridiculous." The President writes this morning.

We're looking at real estate realities next, the outlook on housing. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New concerns about the health of the housing market. October new home sales sliding to the lowest level in more than two and-a-half years. It is the latest sign that rising interest rates are hitting the market.

Joining us now is Rogers Healy and Associates real estate owner and CEO, Rogers Healy. Good to see you Rogers. Thanks very much for joining us.

Are we seeing a slowdown --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGERS HEALY, CEO, ROGERS HEALY AND ASSOCIATES: Good morning. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: -- in housing and tell us how severe it is.

HEALY: It's not severe. I mean first of all, what we do is seasonal, right. Especially in residential, it is seasonal. And so this time of year we do see a slowdown. But obviously the last two years, really the last four or five years it's been really, really, really, really, really, really busy and really, really good.

But it has slowed down a little bit. And for interest rates to get closer to 5 percent, it's more expensive for the house the person thought they could afford. Now they really can't. So, you know, that has definitely slowed us down but the market is still fine.

MCDOWELL: Rogers -- sorry, Mike. Rogers -- you're in Texas.

HEALY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Are you worried about the impact on the major drop in oil prices on the Texas economy and on your business?

HEALY: You said do I worry about it?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Because you would hear -- everybody's in the oil business or at least they know somebody in the oil business, oil and gas business, so you would hear from them that they're concerned, that they're getting ready to cut, you know, cut jobs. They're not going to pass on a pay increase. I just wonder what you're hearing on the ground about the impact there on real estate.

HEALY: Yes, I guess I should start with yes, ma'am, I will tell you.

Yes. You know, we saw this happen about seven or eight years ago. And people just kind of sit on the sideline. But I'm in Dallas. So in Dallas we don't really see the effect of the oil and gas market like if Houston would. But it's still people just cautious, right, and prior they were cautiously optimistic. Now they're just a little bit hesitant.

But just like the real estate market, the oil and gas market is cyclical and goes in waves. But we're really not concerned. I think I saw this morning that oil is about to be under $50 a barrel for the first time in a little bit. But it's going to come back, just like everything always does.

MURPHY: Rogers -- you hear so much about millennials and their desire to rent versus owning a home. I see that changing at some point. Are there any signs of that yet?

HEALY: Yes, I saw a meme the other day that said millennials are walking around here like they rent the place. And --

BARTIROMO: I like that.

HEALY: Yes, so we work a lot with millennials. And you know, obviously the American dream has been, will always be owning your own piece of real estate. But, you know, the shift is going to happen I think with rental rates -- I think rental rates are going to eventually start to decrease. And we've seen this with rental rates as real estate rates have increased as far as owning a home, rental rates have increased too.

So I think it's going to become a beggar's can't be choosers situation. And eventually millennials and especially the millennials that are in real estate -- they're going to go toward leaning towards purchasing a home.

But right now they're obviously still renting. But, you know, when they want to start a family, when they want to go and actually have savings, they're going to probably go do something more strategic.

FREEMAN: Rogers -- James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal", news side of our paper had a story about people doing cash-out refinancings even as rates go up. So they're taking the equity out of the home, they're accepting a mortgage with a higher interest rate.

This doesn't sound like a recipe for healthy financial system when the downturn comes. I guess in some ways maybe there is already a downturn in real estate. But are you seeing a lot of these cash-out refinancings where the borrower ends up much more with a higher rate and less equity in the home?

HEALY: Yes, it sounds like they need a better financial advisor, not a better realtor. And you know, these people that got in over their heads back in 2005, 2006, 2007 -- you know, that was the big foreclosure boom that I experienced with my first group of clients.

But these guys that are doing cash-out refinances, they didn't manage their money, you know, strategically probably all across the board. I mean if they've got enough equity in their home and you know, you've seen a year over year 4 percent to 8 percent compounded adjustment, yes -- hello? Sorry.

If you see a year over year, you're going to try to find some money somewhere. That's going to always happen. But we're not going to have the foreclosures that we had back in the days of the big short.

BARTIROMO: Rogers -- good to see you. Thanks so much.

HEALY: You too. Thank you. Have a good day.

BARTIROMO: Rogers Healy here.

Coming up, stock market surge - we break down Wall Street's reaction to Fed chairman Powell's remarks yesterday that he erased November's losses. It was a 650-point move on the Dow.

We're talking with the chairman of UBS, Axel Weber in studio next, exclusive.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages. We are well off of the lows of the morning actually. Markets have been under pressure this morning after a powerful rally yesterday that took the market soaring. Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell gave a positive read of on the economy yesterday sending markets higher across the board. Powell gave some insight on what the Federal Reserve's plans are moving forward.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: There is no preset policy path. We'll be paying very close attention to what incoming economic and financial data are telling us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that, the markets soared. The Dow re-raising its November decline on Powell's speech, finishing higher by more than 600 points, the Dow Industrials on track for the best week since the 2016 election.

This morning, European markets are higher as well. Take a look at the FT- 100 up three quarters of one percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris up two thirds of a percent and the DAX Index in Germany up a quarter of a percent.

Markets were mixed overnight in Asia. As you can see here, fractional moves although the Shanghai Composite in China down 1-1/3 percent.

Investing in vaping, tobacco giant Altria is looking to take a stake in the embattled e-cigarette company Juul. Details on that deal potentially coming up.

Then the future of the future, the phone of the future, rather, we are taking a look at the new 3D phone that doesn't need any special glasses. We'll show it to you.

Plus, hunting season could be over, why Dick's Sporting season is thinking about pulling hunting gear from its stores all together.

But first this, our top story this half an hour, Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell, he said the economy is doing well yesterday. He addressed the New York Economic Club yesterday. Powell said that the Fed is close to fulfilling its goals of promoting maximum employment and price stability.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

POWELL: The unemployment rate is 3.7 percent. A 49-year low and many other measures of labor market strength are at or near historic bests. Inflation is near our two percent target and the economy is growing at an annual rate of about three percent, well above most estimates of its longer run trend.

My FOMC colleagues and I as well as many private sector economists are forecasting continued solid growth, low unemployment and inflation remaining near two percent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Those comments particularly about being close to neutral on rates, two percent, getting the attention of investors. The Dow Industrials shot up as you can see, closing up better than 600 points on the session. That was 2-1/2 percent.

Joining me right now in a Fox Business exclusive, UBS chairman, Axel Weber. Great to see you Mr. Chairman. Thank you for joining us.

AXEL WEBER, CHAIRMAN, UBS: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Jay Powell yesterday?

WEBER: I think as a former central banker I would say there was nothing extraordinary he said. He was just acknowledging that by now after several rate hikes over two or three years, the Fed is close to neutral. And I think the real issue for markets is they have been quite jibbery this year because three major expectation of what really supported equity markets in the past are starting to be questioned.

The first is will earning growth continue to be as strong as it has? And there's some doubt about that. The second one is really monetary policy that was a major supporter of equity, markets is starting to be at neutral, so it's less supportive, it may actually become restrictive. And the final point is the economy data, the economic data we're seeing are more mixed.

So, there is a mix of head winds that the markets are experiencing that we haven't seen in that combination for the last couple of years.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, there are other things that the Fed is dealing with. I mean, you were the chairman of the Bundesbank -- the president of the Bundesbank. And you didn't have the kind of issue of winding down a $3 trillion balance sheet, right? That's one of the issues that the Federal Reserve faces right now, not just raising rates but winding down the balance sheet. Are they going to be able to do that without tightening too much too fast?

WEBER: But that's exactly what Jay was pointing at. There are two issues that they face. First one is they need to contain inflation because with the economy doing well, there is a risk that inflation will go up. It's been pretty contained. The Fed was able in this cycle to raise rates, roughly at half the speed of what they did in the past, and they've traveled about half the distance.

And the real question is, I don't think that normalization of monetary policy will be completed in the current cycle. It will take another economic cycle to really go to neutral. Because after a very long period of very low interest rates, raising interest rates has happened very cautious, but the balance sheets are still very, very expanded. So they'll continue to reduce the balance sheet.

But my expectation is they won't even go back to where the Fed's balance sheet was before the crisis. Central banks have now become a much larger central counterparty in markets. And for that, I think structurally central bank balance sheets will be larger.

And I think there's good reasons to be cautious about normalizing monetary policy because we're coming out of a 10 year low interest rate environment and therefore you have to be cautious and you should not overshoot. You need to look at the economy where central bank support has been taken for granted for a decade, and weaning that off has to happen with some eyes on a really cautious normalization. In can't stay where they are for a long time because financial markets stability could be threatened. And that balance was pointed out by Jay Powell yesterday.

BARTIROMO: But of course, as rates move higher and as we see commodities prices facing the impact of perhaps tariffs, you're seeing this worry about margins. So market has been very volatile. Are you seeing margin pressure at UBS?

WEBER: No, I think what we're expecting going forward is there will be continued to be challenges in the markets and margin pressure will arise here and there. But the real challenge that I think the markets will have is liquidity.

As the ECB gets off their purchase program for the first time in the last 10 years, central bank balance sheets globally, the sum of what central banks are doing will no longer support the economy. It will no longer expand balance sheet. Central bank balance sheets globally will start to shrink and that is a new phenomenon. Because so far, the ECB's expansion and the bank of Japan's expansion has more than made up the shrinking of the balance sheet by the Fed. That will change at the end of the year.

So, there's clearly going to be some headwinds for the next year economy. There's clearly going to be some headwinds from -- you know, the effects of the -- of the tax reductions and physical reforms in the U.S. are starting to ban. Market growth is going to be more normalized. But there's no reason to worry, I don't see an imminent recession on the horizon, maybe a soft spot in the economy for the next first half of the year.

Because one thing that has taken toll now is these trade disputes which didn't really impact the economy but now with China, U.S. heading ahead in a sort of more conflicted way, many global firms are re-wiring their global production chains. So multinationals are really changing the way where they produce and how they produce and that has taken a toll for a short- term on the economy.

So, I expect the first quarter, the second quarter next year to be quite weak and that is a soft spot. It's not a recession. Most data that we're seeing are not in the typical pattern of what usually you see before a recession.

BARTIROMO: So you are expecting a weak first and second quarter in 2019 then?

WEBER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and we saw some of that in what you said when you reported earnings last month, they were 26 percent above the expectations. But you set new targets in terms of what you want to achieve.

One of those targets is you want to bring more money into your wealth management business. Tell us about it.

WEBER: It's true. So, what we did is basically reaffirmed our strategy. You know, about seven years ago when we looked at the strategy we changed the way we ran the bank. Now, a couple of years later, we've given different market developments. We wanted to look at whether that's still in place and we felt that is the case.

But we have some targeted growth initiative. One is really our ultra business and we're the only truly global wealth manager with a large amount of clients in the ultra space that is the richest individual and the richest people in our economies. And we want to grow that business by $70 billion over the next three years, largely focused on growing our U.S. business.

And that is something where we feel -- you know, unlike a couple of years ago we're expanding our global business and in particular with the U.S. being a strong market, we're expanding our U.S. business.

BARTIROMO: How do you do that, Axel? How do you that grow a business when you're seeing such uncertainty and worry in a market where the market will be down 600 points one day and up 600 the next day? How do you invest that money and make the case for these very wealthy individuals that you want UBS to be handling that allocation?

WEBER: Well, I think what you're seeing in the next few years is diversification will become much more important than it has been in the past even for U.S. based investors.

So, U.S. based investors typically have a very strong bias in their portfolio towards U.S. investments. As the U.S. economy is starting to see some soft spots, and its emerging markets are coming out of a correction, you would start see investors looking globally at a different mix between developed markets and emerging markets. You will also see them look at a different balance between fixed income and equity investment. And as global investor we can bring that diversification to clients and we can help them invest.

Part of what we're also very good at and what we're expanding is investment in sustainability. And that in particular is very attractive for the richest -- you know, clients that we have because they want to see their investments also raise sustainability and many of the clients around the globe look at sustainable investment as a new form which is under- represented in their portfolio. And we have a targeted initiative in that area.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. And I know these are investors that want long-term performance. They're not looking to -- you know, make major moves overnight. I want to get back to that because that's an important point.

Let me get your reaction though first to this breaking news overnight and that is about Deutsche Bank, a competitor of yours, authorities raided Deutsche Bank's headquarters as part of a probe into money laundering. Now there's expectations that this company has gotten so weak it's going to need some kind of a takeover. Anybody's guess whether or not the German government will allow its largest bank to be acquired by another but will UBS be interested in acquiring Deutsche Bank?

WEBER: No, I think what we've said already in the past is we're looking for targeted growth in our areas that where we have expertise and we're a wealth manager. And wealth management and asset management, that's the core of what we do and we continue to look at that.

We don't rule out inorganic options but it will not be full-fledged mergers. It will be more targeted acquisitions in the areas where we already excel, where we've feel that we have a value proposition and we want to expand that value proposition.

BARTIROMO: Any issues to that are still ongoing that you can tell us about with regard to UBS in terms of any of this regulatory or rulings from -- I know the French court was ruling on a trial back in February for UBS. Is that now in the rear view mirror for the company?

WEBER: It's not yet. We have a -- we have a verdict that comes out in February. So, there will be no new news until then. We're still in discussion with authorities.

We have not foregone the ability to settle the two remaining issues that we have and for us really what matters going forward is to not have new issues emerge. So, we're very focused on compliance. We're very focused on operational risk and dealing with them, cyber resilience. So, we really want to avoid problems in the future and we've learned our lessons from the past.

BARTIROMO: And I know that was a priority of yours when you first stepped into the role.

WEBER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Let's get the bad news out of the way and deal with this. Your thoughts on the regulatory environment in general. The president to the U.S. obviously has rolled back a number of regulations. How does the industry change from that standpoint?

WEBER: I think the U.S. is setting the pace here. What we've seen is almost a decade of re-regulation. What is important now is -- you know, like, with monetary policy normalization, do not overdo it.

Of course, you can always rollout additional regulation but I think banks now need some certainty around the regulatory environment in the future. So that they can refocused on supporting the economy and that is happening in the United States. And I see that happening with some delay in Europe and in Asia-Pacific.

In Switzerland we're discussing some of the final regulations around (INAUDIBLE) three implementation and too big to fail. But my expectation is by summer next year we'll have more regulatory certainty and then we can refocused on doing business and doing business well.

BARTIROMO: And the investor sentiment right now in the face of all of this, how does it look? Are you worried about investing in this -- in this market today?

WEBER: I think we see a lot of our clients are on the sidelines. There's a huge amount of cash sitting on the sidelines. But you know in (INAUDIBLE) the mood was very good and I was actually one of the few that wasn't as positive about it.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WEBER: We're seeing now a correction that has gone further and was more pronounced than I expected then. I think the market is overdoing it in the other direction.

BARTIROMO: Overdue in the other direction.

WEBER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Axel, it's great to see you.

WEBER: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. The chairman of UBS, Axel Weber. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The president is tweeting this morning on tariffs, here's what he just wrote, billions of dollars pouring into the coffers of the USA because of the tariffs being charged to China. There's a long way to go. If companies do not want to pay tariffs, build in the USA. Otherwise, let's just make our country richer than ever before. Writes the president.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: One, it will never pay down the debt. You're running over trillion dollar annual budget deficit right now. And number two, its attacks on people who buy stuff from overseas. So, let's not brag about taxing the American people.

BARTIROMO: You've had a problem with these tariffs from day one and we are seeing an impact in terms of companies making moves like Volvo this morning.

MCDOWELL: Right, and that's actually in relation -- Volvo is holding off on hiring down in South Carolina because of the retaliatory tariff from China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There's now a 40 percent tariff on car imports from the U.S. into China. So that's hurting companies that make cars here and export them to China and that's a lot of the foreign manufacturers that have plans here.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we've got a deal in the works. Altria Group reportedly in talks to acquire juul labs, that's the e-cigarette company. Cheryl Casone with the details now in headlines. Cheryl, over you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It's interesting, Maria. The Journal says that Altria, of course the maker of Marlboro and parliament cigarettes is looking to take in a significant minority stake in Juul. Right now there's no definitive deal on the table, but Juuls value by investors this summer about $16 billion. Shares of Altria are higher in the premarket right now. So stock to watch for all of you more than half a percent.

Well, Dick's Sporting Goods is considering dropping hunting supplies from over 700 stores because of declining sales. It's already pulled hunting gear from 10 stores. Shares of Dick's Sporting Goods are up about 26 percent so far this year.

And remember Big Mouth Billy Bass? He's back and he can talk back too.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Don't worry, be happy. Don't worry, be happy now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Everyone's favorite wall-mounted singing fish is now programmed to respond to Amazon's Alexa. He will lip sync to Alexa's voice and dance to sounds fom Amazon music when you pair it with a compatible echo device, Maria. Fun for the whole family.

BARTIROMO: I like it.

CASONE: I love the singing fish.

BARTIROMO: That is fun. Thank you, Cheryl.

Coming up, it is 3D without the glasses, we're checking out the brand-new cell phone that's aiming to shake up the business. My exclusive interview with ROK Group co-founder John Paul DeJoria is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. 3D content with a click, a mobile brand is aiming to shake up the cell phone industry with a game-changing new device. In a Fox Business exclusive right now, ROKiT is revealing its first ever smartphone that allows users to watch 3D content without any 3D glasses. Joining us right now is the co-founder of ROK Group, co-founder of Patron Spirits and co-founder and chairman of John Paul Mitchell Systems, he is John Paul DeJoria and it is good to see you, John Paul.

JOHN PAUL DEJORIA, CO-FOUNDER OF ROK GROUP, CO-FOUNDER OF PATRON SPIRITS AND CO-FOUNDER AND CHAIRMAN, JOHN PAUL MITCHELL SYSTEMS: Always a pleasure. You know, we're launching these phones with the same philosophy we have at all our Paul Mitchell Schools, give back first. All of our students participate, you know, in raising funds to help people out. So, we thought to start a business, why not change the dynamics. First thing we did was before (INAUDIBLE) we gave away free to homeless veterans that were on the street there.

BARTIROMO: How great.

DEJORIA: Gave them the phone and at the same time --

BARTIROMO: And then you gave them for also veterans.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER & CEO OF ROSECLIFF: You obviously conquered the market with shampoo then tequila. So I'm betting on you not against you on this, but going after Apple seems like a kind of tough person to go after. Can you unseat the iPhone or just take some of their market share?

DEJORIA: Well, what I'm looking at is not unseating anybody. I want everybody to prosper. I'm looking at a brand-new field, it's a whole new area. Granted, they'll sell for under $300 each and it's a smartphone that does unbelievable things. We have a bundle that goes with it.

For example, telemedicine, where seven days a week, 24 hours a day, there's a doctor on the phone with you. Other technologies we're working with the NASA as one of our partners that scan the body to do unbelievable health things.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

DEJORIA: We're going to introduce those in about three months from now. So, shall we say we're a bit of a disrupter because the price, no one can believe these smartphones are going to sell for under $300 but they are --

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: When you talked about giving away some of the phones. That seems like almost giving it away compared to a $1,000 or more phone. What are we giving up if we're the customer and we're getting this $300 phone with 3D images, what are we not getting that you would get in a more expensive phone?

DEJORIA: An extra $700 or $800 added on. No, this is a very advanced smartphone and it has different things you can bundle on it. Life insurance, but this is for dollars.

Give you an idea, recently we took the country of India, we're wi-fiing the entire country of India, to help the lower classes become higher classes because we're putting them on the internet and some of our technologies doing that. And we're looking at right now, doing a city in the United States so. People, no matter where you are, could try (INAUDIBLE) and make phone calls anywhere in the world for less than $5.00 a month.

BARTIROMO: You are a true entrepreneur and innovator. J.P., good to see you.

DEJORIA: It's always a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We'll be watching the developments.

DEJORIA: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: John Paul DeJoria. Still ahead, spotlight on America's Heartland, next.
