urn:contentItem:42BR-NC30-009B-G38T-00000-00Release of the Human Genetic Code Sends Celera's Stock Soaring; Crucial Court Ruling Rocks the Music Business and Napster2001-02-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:50ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Ron Hill, Craig VenterBusinessSHOW01021200V19Release of the Human Genetic Code Sends Celera's Stock Soaring; Crucial Court Ruling Rocks the Music Business and NapsterStuart Varney, Willow Bay, Steve Young, John Metaxas, Terry Keenan, Bruce Francis, Casey Wian, Wolf Blitzer, Kitty Pilgrim, Fred Katayama, Susan Lisovicz, Myron Kandel

The Dow surged today, its first winning session in a week. One factor fuelling that rally was the hope that when the Fed Reserve chairman appears tomorrow before the Senate Banking Committee he will make it clear that more relief on interest rates is on the way. Celera Genomics along with the publicly funded Human Genome Project have published rival genetic maps in a landmark scientific achievement. The two rival groups racing to publish "the book of life" finished with a much smaller volume than anyone expected: about 30,000 genes in the human code instead of 100,000. That could mean the idea that a single gene equals a disease is wrong and that genes work in combination.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, the Dow surges, now back within shooting distance of 11,000. Was it a Greenspan-inspired rally?

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: The landmark release of the human genetic code sending Celera's stock soaring. We'll talk with the company president.

VARNEY: A crucial court ruling rocks the music business: Are the days numbered for Napster?

BAY: And a top firm apologizes after sparking protest for hiring the former president to speak. Is Bill Clinton damaged goods on the chat circuit?

ANNOUNCER: Live from coast to coast, this is MONEYLINE.

BAY: Welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: Hello, Willow. Good evening, everyone. I'm Stuart Varney in New York.

Our top story tonight, a powerful blue chip bounce as investors await testimony from Alan Greenspan. The Dow surged today, its first winning session in a week. One factor fuelling that rally: the hope that when the Fed chairman appears tomorrow before the Senate Banking Committee he will make it clear that more relief on interest rates is on the way.

The Dow gained 165 points today -- that's 1 1/2 percent. It closed at 10,946. Big Board volume was more than a billion shares. But the Nasdaq, well, that was weighed down by fears that the data storage sector is in a slump. More on that later. The index gained just 18 points. It closed the session at 2,489. The volume on the Nasdaq today, 1.7 billion shares.

The S&P 500 on the upside, again at 15 points, closing out the day at 1,330.

BAY: Stuart, Chairman Greenspan wasn't the only buzz worthy topic on Wall Street today. Genomics was also grabbing the spotlight.

Celera Genomics along with the publicly funded Human Genome Project have published rival genetic maps in a landmark scientific achievement. Wall Street seemed to be impressed. Celera jumped more than 6, rallying along with certain other biotech stocks, including Gilead Sciences, Affymetrix, Protein Design Labs and Human Genome Sciences.

But just how much of today's news is a breakthrough for investors?

Steve Young reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The two rival groups racing to publish "the book of life" finished with a much smaller volume than anyone expected: about 30,000 genes in the human code instead of 100,000. That could mean the idea that a single gene equals a disease is wrong and that genes work in combination. If so, pharmaceutical companies could find that their individual gene patents are worth less.

TODD NELSON, DAIN RAUSCHER WESSELLS: Wall Street should care because we originally said we had 500 drugable targets. The promise of genomics was to get that to 5,000 to 10,000 drugable targets. There's a relationship between gene discovery and drug discovery. And now that people think there are fewer genes, is that worth less?

YOUNG: Nelson says the answer is no. He thinks with other techniques a larger number of genes still will be discovered. But even the head of a biotech company that still says there could be 100,000 human genes is cautious about how long it will take to hit paydirt.

WILLIAM HASELTINE, CEO, HUMAN GENOME SCIENCES: We put it at more like three to five years before the first drugs are out, 10 years before there are many drugs out and 20 years before this type of science changes medicine as we know it.

YOUNG: Celera, the private company some now say has a better blueprint than the consortium, soared 15 percent on publication of its genetic map. But the stock's below $50, down from nearly $250 just a year ago.

Celera's been far more volatile than most biotech stocks in an index Wall Street analysts follow closely. It's up 20 percent in the same time period.

It's quite a comedown if humans don't have 100,000 but just 30,000 genes, only twice as many as a worm.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: But the head of the U.S. consortium member says this has to be good news: the genetic haystack is two-thirds smaller -- Willow.

BAY: That is the optimistic scientific opinion. Steve Young, thanks. Will this scientific breakthrough led to investment riches? Later in the broadcast, we'll ask the driving force behind Celera, Craig Venter.

VARNEY: Well, Willow, as we mentioned earlier, tech stocks were held back today on concerns that the data storage business is struggling. Blame those concerns on one company: Emulex. Shares of the data storage equipment maker cratered after warning late Friday that some companies were putting off orders. And if that continued, Emulex said it would not meet quarterly forecasts.

Emulex today lost a staggering 37 points, nearly 50 percent of its value, coming all the way down to $40 at 40 3/8. Quite a setback in what's been a rough year for the company victimized, remember, last summer by a hoax that slammed the stock.

And the damage today was hardly contained to just Emulex. Let's go to John Metaxas at the Nasdaq marketsite with a look at the Emulex fallout and more -- John.

JOHN METAXAS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Stuart, it really was a mixed session here. We finished up. We broke a three-day losing streak at the Nasdaq. But the Emulex story was a drag early in the trading and counterbalanced by, of course, the strength in the genomics stocks.

Emulex did affect other companies in the storage -- data storage area, including QLogic. Emulex was downgraded today by Asha Kumark (ph) at U.S. Bank Corp Piper Jaffray, who also downgraded QLogic, saying they face same of the same earnings risk: that slowdown in storage technology spending. QLogic down $15.

Brocade Communications, a maker of fiber channel switches, down $11 and change despite the fact that they'll be entering the Nasdaq 100 tomorrow. And McData, a supplier to data storage makers, down $6 on the day.

Network Appliance, which beat earnings expectations last week by a penny but had disappointing revenues, was actually down $4 1/2 but finished up on the session.

Biotechs were up 4 percent. The chip stocks also surged today, and they were some support underneath the Nasdaq. Intel among the gainer as was Xilinx and Broadcom. PMC-Sierra continued lower on concerns about that Cisco inventory buildup. But Applied Materials, a leading chip equipment maker, up better than a dollar. They report earnings tomorrow. Some mixed commentary on that stock out of the brokerage community today.

Looking at our big caps, we had Cisco Systems surging nicely from their gains last week, but the stock is still down 25 percent in the month of February. Sun, another big gainer among the big caps. But for those gainers, we had losers in Microsoft and Oracle.

So it was a mixed session today, concerns about the future earnings, and we're waiting for Greenspan tomorrow -- Stuart, Willow. BAY: We are indeed. John Metaxas at the Nasdaq marketsite, thanks, John.

The Emulex effect was not confined to the Nasdaq today. One of the company's big customers got hit on the Big Board in very heavy trading: EMC.

Terry Keenan joins us now from the New York Stock Exchange with more on that and all the action today on Wall Street -- Terry.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Willow, I will get to EMC in just a moment. It's sort of one of the stealth tech stocks here, one of the biggest on the New York Stock Exchange. Because it isn't included on the Dow, a lot of people forget about it. They didn't forget about it today. It was down sharply.

Let's get to the Dow first. It posted a triple-digit gain for the second Monday in a row, but you may notice that the Dow still can't make a convincing charge above 11,000. And that, of course, has been the case now for more than a year.

Today, investors waiting for an encouraging word from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan tomorrow when he testifies before Congress. They got some positive words today from Kathy Mynahan (ph), the head of the Boston Fed. She said that the Fed's two rate cuts this year are already helping out the economy.

That said, investors today stuck with mostly the safer, more defensive names. They were the big movers, although 25 of the Dow 30 stocks did manage to gain here today. Some nice market breadth.

Here are the standouts: Johnson & Johnson up more than 3 percent after Banc America upgraded the stock from a buy to a strong buy. IBM also having a good day despite allegations in a new book that Big Blue made $10 million selling equipment to the Nazis during World War II. Didn't hurt the stock today. Boeing having a strong day as did Wal- Mart. Its Mexican division reported a 5.2 percent increase in same- store sales. The stock up more than 5 percent. And GE also up nearly 5 percent today. Goldman Sachs' Jack Kelly (ph) listing the stock as one of its favorites -- his favorites.

And Honeywell, G.E.'s merger partner, also gaining about the same amount today.

As for the market breadth here, it was positive and very positive as you could see: 19 to 11 in favor of advancers. Volume did remain on the light; just over a billion shares traded here.

Now, let's take a look at EMC. The computer storage company having another tough day on that Emulex news. Traded down more than $2. Also news that last week it laid off 3 percent of its workforce. Wall Street had been hoping that the storage sector would be immune to the slowdown in the rest of technology. That obviously is not the case. EMC shares have been hammered of late, down almost 50 percent from a high about 100, set last year, and down 18 percent, as you can see year there, year to date -- Stuart. VARNEY: All right. That's Terry Keenan at the Big Board. Thanks, Terry.

Thousands of miles away from Wall Street today, a ruling that truly rocked the music industry and fans of Napster. The popular online music swapping service was dealt a blow from a federal court in California, which concluded Napster is infringing on copyrights. But the service is still up and running.

Bruce Francis joins us now with the details of today's complex decision.

What do you have, Bruce?

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Up and running for now, Stuart.

Bedtime for Napster? Not yet. The service stays up and running while a lower court figures out issues like identifying copyrighted files. But today, the recording industry clearly gained the upper hand in its love-hate -- well, mostly hate -- relationship with Napster.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS (voice-over): No rest for Napster user Peter Sayer this past weekend: a rush to find music before a potential shutdown yielded a bonanza.

PETER SAYER, NAPSTER USER: Million -- about a million other users run to it as well, and that creates a large volume of shared files so there's more out there to download and we go nuts downloading.

FRANCIS: Napster, which allows users to exchange recorded music over the Internet, plays on for Sayer and some 50 million other registered users, but perhaps not for long. A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled that an earlier order shutting down Napster has to be modified. Once it is, though, the service could be halted.

In a slam-dunk for the recording industry, the Ninth District Court of Appeals found that "Napster knew or had reason to know of its users' infringement of plaintiffs' copyrights."

Napster CEO Hank Barry vowed to appeal.

HANK BARRY, CEO, NAPSTER: We believe -- and this is contrary to what the court ruled today -- that Napster users are not copyright infringers, and we will pursue every legal avenue to keep Napster operating.

FRANCIS: The recording industry, including Warner Music, which like CNN is owned by AOL Time Warner, couldn't be happier.

HILARY ROSEN, PRESIDENT & CEO, RIAA: … that a business model built on infringement is not only morally wrong but legally wrong, and we're very gratified that the Ninth Circuit today agreed with us 100 percent.

FRANCIS: Last fall, German entertainment giant Bertelsmann broke ranks with the recording industry and invested in Napster and struck a deal to develop a subscription version. And while he's still too young to legally drown his sorrows over today's ruling in a beer, Napster's founder Shawn Fanning says that effort continues.

SHAWN FANNING, FOUNDER, NAPSTER: I'm focused on building this better service, and I still hope to have it in place this year.

FRANCIS: But fans of a free Napster might not stick around.

MIKE STEINBERG, NAPSTER USER: You know, just as I guess I got into this one, I could easily get into another one if it was the same -- same idea and you wouldn't have to subscribe to it.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: And Napster could appeal the injunction and the rest of the decision to the Supreme Court. If so, the company should hope that attorney David Boies has better luck this time with the nation's highest bench. Boies last Supreme Court case: the Gore challenge to the Florida election results.

And Stuart, as for how long this all takes out, more than a few days they're expecting, but probably less than a few months: a narrow window for Napster-lovers.

VARNEY: Understood. Bruce, thanks very much.

And just ahead on MONEYLINE, you've heard the expression any press is good press, but is that true for a former president causing a ruckus on the lecture circuit?

Also, as the new president pushes his military spending plan, we'll look at which companies may win and lose the war for dollars. Willow and I will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "Tech Watch," titans of the digital world gathered in sunny California today at the Goldman Sachs conference, and tried to convince Wall Street that despite the recent slowdown, their business outlook is still bright.

Casey Wian spent the day there and caught up with some of the tech leaders, including one whose stock was under pressure today on Wall Street -- Casey.

CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, it's actually turned cloudy here in La Quinta, California at the Goldman Sachs technology conference, where companies are trying to convince Wall Street analysts and money managers that despite an economic slowdown and a weak performance by technology stocks, their business prospects remain bright. This morning, the conference got under way with a keynote speech by Thomas Siebel, chairman and CEO of Siebel Systems. His company makes customer relationship management software, known as CRM. Siebel says there's a fundamental shift under way at the companies who are his customers -- automakers, banks and telecoms -- that will keep his business strong.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

THOMAS SIEBEL, CHAIRMAN & CEO, SIEBEL SYSTEMS: In the future, the way that they're going to do business is any way the customer wants to do business, any time, any place, any language, any currency, any channel: over the Internet, through retail, through the call center, over the Web, and the Web TV, the kiosk, what have you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WIAN: Siebel says he expects the CRM market to grow to about $6.8 billion this year. That's 50 percent over -- 50 percent growth over last year.

Another presentation came from -- excuse me -- EMC Chairman Mike Reuttgers. He warned against what he called a wall of worry that's standing in the way of technology stocks. Reuttgers says he's seen little evidence of any pullback in technology spending by the companies he deals with, because, as he put it, the smart companies are going to spend right through this economic downturn. He also talked about the debate over a hard or soft economic landing. He says neither of those is likely to happen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE REUTTGERS, CHAIRMAN, EMC: I don't think it's either a hard landing or a soft landing. If there's only a two-quarter slowdown, people are going to want to accelerate out the other side. So I've called it a touch-and-go landing, where you let the wheels touch and then you accelerate out of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WIAN: Despite all that rosy talk, EMC and other storage stocks were dragged down by what happened to Emulex, which you talked about earlier, Willow. And we will be hearing from Emulex executives at this conference tomorrow and they'll be subjected to, I'm sure, some very tough questioning -- Willow.

BAY: All right, Casey, we're looking forward to that tomorrow. Casey Wian reporting, thanks.

Coming up next, Southern California's struggling utility gets its day in court. Will the company be allowed to raise rates on customers? We'll give you the details on the decision. Stuart and I will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK) VARNEY: Ford and Navistar are hitching up. The two industry heavyweights announced today plans for a joint venture to build commercial trucks at Navistar's facility in Mexico. The trucks will be marketed and sold separately in the U.S. The companies said they will also explore opportunities in smaller commercial vehicles and diesel engines as well.

The move comes as demand for trucks has been running out of steam. Navistar stock, which is off 35 percent from its 52-week high, lost another 86 cents today while Ford picked up 88 cents.

Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed

BAY: In other corporate headlines today, oil services giant Schlumberger agreed to buy information technology firm Sema for 5.2 billion. Schlumberger will use Sema to expand its IT strategy, a business it wants to build further and is hoping will generate more stable revenue.

But investors panned the deal and Schlumberger stock lost more than $9 to close at 69. Sema gained just better than two.

Potomac Electric Power Company agreed to buy Delaware-based utility, Conectiv for about 2.2 billion. If approved, the deal will allow Potomac to have a transmission system that runs between Washington, D.C. and Wilmington, Delaware, a key link that would make it one of the largest electricity delivery companies on the East Coast.

On the news, Potomac stock gained 50 cents and Connectiv also powered higher up more than 1 1/4.

Today, a Southern California judge dealt a blow to the state's second-largest electrical utility, ruling against Socal Edison's request to raise rates on customers. The company, deep in debt, asked the judge to let it hike retail prices because wholesale prices have soared, costing the utility billions. Most retail rates in the state have been capped since the industry was deregulated back in 1996.

Today's decision was a setback to the utility, but it's not over yet. The two sides go back to court in March to schedule a full trial on the issue.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL LOCKYEAR, ATTORNEY GENERAL, STATE OF CALIFORNIA: Rates could have been substantially increased today depending on what the federal court did, and so the fact that the court on abstained from entering an order that the plaintiffs requested is good for rate payers, but there's still lots and lots of further work that needs to be done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: Let's take a look at how California's electrical utilities did today. Both PG and Edison International, which owns Southern California Edison, fell sharply after the decision, but trimmed their losses to end off less than one.

VARNEY: And coming up on MONEYLINE, Attorney General John Ashcroft wades into the Marc Rich presidential pardon controversy. We'll tell you about his first news conference and his new role after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Profile," Craig Venter, the president of Celera Genomics. The man who once flirted with becoming a professional surfer instead joined the Navy in 1965, where he served as a medical corpsman in Vietnam.

In 1975, he earned his doctorate in physiology and pharmacology. In 1984, he joined the National Institutes of Health. In '98, he launched Celera, and two years later, finished the first rough draft of the human genome.

Venter has left open the door to possibly studying his own genetic makeup. His response: "Why not if that's the business I'm in?"

Mr. Venter joins us in our next half hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Attorney General John Ashcroft is suggesting that he'd work with Congress on its investigation of the Marc Rich pardon. More on that now from Wolf Blitzer in the "MONEYLINE News Digest" -- Wolf.

WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Stuart. It was John Ashcroft's first news conference as attorney general. He wouldn't comment directly on whether the Justice Department should name a special counsel to investigate former President Clinton's controversial pardon. But he did describe the president's right to pardon as -- quote -- "very substantial."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ASHCROFT, U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: When a president exercises that right, he operates, I would hope, within the limits of the Constitution, and there are very few limits in that respect. And I don't believe that I can reach a conclusion beyond that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: Ashcroft said he would take seriously a House committee's request to grant immunity for Rich's ex-wife, Denise, in exchange for her testimony. He added that immunity has complicated prosecutions like Iran-Contra, but said he'll bear that in mind if Congress needs to go ahead and do its work.

In Georgia today, President Bush today visited troops at Fort Stewart and spelled out his plans to spend more money on the military.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Today I'm announcing that are proposed 2002 budget will add $5.7 billion in new spending on the people of our military.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: The budget proposal includes money to boost pay and benefits for service personnel. Also today, rescue crews say the search for nine people missing in Friday's submarine accident off Hawaii may end shortly. Investigators say they're focusing on why the USS Greenville wasn't using its most accurate sonar when it surfaced into a Japanese fishing boat.

And a study by federal investigators has found that U.S. airlines are taking steps to improve customer service, but they're still not addressing the biggest cause of dissatisfaction, delayed and canceled flights.

Finally, ready for its closeup, the asteroid Eros. NASA successfully landed its picture-snapping NEAR probe on the 21-mile- long space rock today. It's the first landing ever by a spacecraft on an asteroid.

And I'll have much more on those stories and the rest of the day's top stories on WOLF BLITZER REPORTS, including an interview with Ralph Nader. That's at 8:00 p.m. Eastern, 5:00 on the West Coast -- Stuart and Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Wolf.

Coming up in our second half hour, much more on the market action. And a preview of Alan Greenspan's testimony tomorrow and a look at why two rate cuts from the Fed has not yet lit a fire under the market.

And later, Clinton and the speaking circuit, another Wall Street giant gears up for the former president: Is it worth the controversy? We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's headlines, a federal appeals court deals a body blow to Napster, holding the online music service responsible for copyright violations. But a court lets the music play on, for now. And Wall Street waits for Alan Greenspan to address the Senate tomorrow. Will the Fed chairman drop any signals about interest rate policy going forward?

Plus, as one Wall Street powerhouse regrets inviting citizen Clinton, others line up to hear from the former president: why speaking fees may keep on coming through all the controversies.

VARNEY: For those of you just joining us, let's get a quick check on today's market action. Blue chip stocks kicked off the week on a tear, posting a triple-digit surge as investors scrambled for the security of some old economy stalwarts.

The Dow rose from the get-go, driven by financial and retailing shares to gain 165 points, moving up to 10,946, and the volume topped a billion shares. Tech stocks also turned their back on early losses, picking up some steam to end 18 points higher at 2,489. 1.7 billion shares moved on the Nasdaq. In the broader market, the S&P 500, a move up there of some 15 points.

But investors spent the day on edge, waiting for key testimony tomorrow from the Fed chairman. Kitty Pilgrim reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KITTY PILGRIM, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It was a bargain basement sale for Dow stocks with all the earmarks of a markdown sale. Big-name stocks such as Johnson & Johnson, Wal-Mart, Boeing, G.E., and IBM managed nice gains.

The comeback couldn't come at a better moment. The Dow closed last week just below break-even for the year. Today's rally put it back in the black.

For the Nasdaq, today's gain did little. The index is still down 12 percent since the end of January, when the Fed last lowered interest rates, failing to offset market pessimism.

ART HOGAN, JEFFERIES & COMPANY: I think what had happened was we bought the market anticipation of the rate cut and we did so much so that I think we had a natural aftereffect of you buy -- you buy on the rumor and sell on the news.

PILGRIM: Now, because the market didn't rally after the Fed's last rate cut, many think the upside is limited. Earnings have been abysmal and tax season may cut into investment capital.

GREG WARR, GREGORY D. WARR & COMPANY: We're seeing minor rallies as far as money managers going in and trying to scoop up stocks, but there's really no support.

PILGRIM: Despite selling since the last rate cut, investors will be turning to their economic guru, expecting reaffirmation. The Fed will stay aggressive on rates. Every lens from camera to microscopic will be on Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan when he heads to Capitol Hill tomorrow.

RICHARD CRIPPS, LEGG MASON: I don't think that he can say much other than the fact that the market is expecting that the Fed is going to cut interest rates one or two if not even three more times, do what it has to do to get the economy to go.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

PILGRIM: Market watchers say the Fed chairman will be walking a fine line. He needs to indicate that the expected rate cuts will be coming without being too pessimistic about economic growth -- Stuart.

VARNEY: A fine line indeed. Kitty Pilgrim, thanks very much.

Well, the markets have indeed been in the doldrums since the Fed's last move on concerns over the state of the economy and also corporate profits. But our next sees some light at the end of the tunnel and suggests this may be the time to step out there and buy.

We're now joined Ron Hill, equity strategist At Brown Brothers Harriman. Ron, welcome back.

RON HILL, BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN: Nice to be here, Stuart.

VARNEY: Is your advice flat-out buy stocks now? If you've got money on the side, put it into stocks, invest fully now?

HILL: Yes, and the reason is because we're at the start of a liquidity lift by the Fed. There have been 13 liquidity cycles in the last 50 years, and the average gain within one year of the start of that cycle has been 40 percent on the S&P 500. Worst year was 30 percent. Best year 67 percent.

VARNEY: So you're simply saying, look, on a historical basis you cannot fight the Fed on the upside or the downside, the Fed is lowering rates, get in there and buy because it will have a market impact flatout?

HILL: That's right. What happens is P/E ratings are going to expand, profits are going to be lousy, but the profits are going down for the same reason that the Fed is lowering rates. The economy is weak and the liquidity comes in there. The money supply is growing three times faster than the nominal economy right now. That's a lot of extra buying power to come into financial assets.

VARNEY: Why are tech stocks lagging behind old-economy Dow industrial type stocks?

HILL: Well, they've obviously had a tremendous run. And if you actually look at last year, it was sort of really a year of two markets. The New York Stock Exchange composite hit a low in March while the Nasdaq hit a high, and then they sort of reversed. The New York Stock Exchange actually hit a new all-time high in September.

The Nasdaq is still suffering after a huge blow off top. But at the same point in time, now you should begin to think about what happens early in the food chain of technology as companies like the semiconductor equipment makers begin to look for orders coming down from the Intels and things like that. Orders beget, sales beget profits, and by then the stocks have already moved. That's one of the reasons you should be watching them now.

VARNEY: Are those the kind of stocks that you would jump into right now? Over and above old-economy stocks, no, you would go for technology flat-out?

HILL: You'd be going for technology and also for retail. Retail actually moves ahead of technology when you get this return to a more cyclical type name in the stock market. So, look at retailers led by sort of the specialty apparel companies, which have already started to move, companies like American Eagle Outfitters, Pacific Sunwear. These should be the flying wedge that lead the retailers higher. As that happens, traditionally what you do is you begin to step away from your health care bet and then you start to look for the timing for the big tech move.

VARNEY: The premise of your argument is that the economy is going to go down like that and then come straight -- it's a V. That's the premise of your argument, isn't it?

HILL: Well, it's a V, but it's sort of a low takeoff. It's -- one of our guys called a modified "VU," because, you know, the second quarter is not going to be anything to write home about, but by the fourth quarter we're probably back toward 3 1/2 percent growth rate on a quarterly annualized rate.

And remember, that's sort of where the Fed would really like to see us. That's their long-term sustainable level of noninflationary growth for this economy.

VARNEY: It's not the old days, 1999, is it?

HILL: No, Stuart. It certainly isn't that. But you know, with the Fed on your side, it's a good time to be looking at stocks again.

VARNEY: Quick question: Have you ever recommended a gold stock in the last 10 years?

HILL: No, sir.

VARNEY: And will you in the next 10?

HILL: I hope not.

VARNEY: Ron Hill, always a pleasure. Thank you very much.

HILL: Thank you, Stuart.

VARNEY: And here's what's just ahead for you. As President Bush considers his military budget, how much do military contractors and defense contractors, investors receive? How much do they stand to cash in on this one? We'll tell you.

Plus, can former President Clinton keep up the earning power given to protests that dogged his recent speech? We will be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Today's moves lifted the S&P 500 back into positive territory for the year. But the broader market may have a major challenge ahead, to post the kind of bull run that would make investors forget about a miserable 2000.

Terry Keenan down at the New York Stock Exchange takes a look "Behind the Numbers" -- Terry. KEENAN: Well, Willow, we just heard it from Ron Hill, and it is the conventional wisdom on Wall Street these days that while earnings will likely be flat or even worse this year, stock prices will go up as investors anticipate an economic and earnings recovery in 2002. In fact, last week, two of Wall Street's leading bulls stuck with their most aggressive price targets even as they cut earnings estimates.

Abby Joseph Cohen, for example, says that she's sticking with her S&P 500 price target of 1,650 by year's end even though consensus profit estimates have dropped. Ed Kerschner, the market strategist at UBS Warburg, is even more optimistic with a target of 1,715, or a P/E of 30 by year's end.

Well, if that sounds expensive, history shows that it is. According to Ned Davis Research, the price/earnings ratio on the S&P 500 has averaged just 14 since 1929, and has fallen to single digits at the start of every major bull market in the 1950s, 1970s and early 1980s.

Only once, according to the folks at Ned Davis, did a bull run begin with a P/E above 20, and that was in 1998 when the Federal Reserve flooded the system with liquidity. In fact, at today's closing price, the S&P 500 sports a P/E ratio of 24.8, right where it was in the summer of 19998. But back then, earnings were still rising, and today they aren't.

The bottom line, while multiples tend to expand in advance of an economic upturn, as Ron Hill just mentioned, this time prices are already at exalted levels relative to their historical norm. It's one reason why more cautious observers on Wall Street, such as Byron Ween (ph) of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, worry that the Fed can't cut rates fast enough to compensate for the big fall-off in earnings growth.

And Stuart, of course, the S&P 500 is only part of the story. The Nasdaq is even more expensive on a historical basis.

VARNEY: Yes, it certainly is, and Terry Keenan, thanks very much. At the Big Board for us, Terry Keenan.

Well, today, President Bush turned his attention to military spending. The commander in chief took his first flight on Air Force One as president to visit troops in Georgia.

Last year, defense stocks soared in anticipation of a Bush presidency. How might they fare now that the details of his military spending plans are becoming clear.

Fred Katayama takes a look in tonight's "Sector Report."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): President Bush promised to boost pay for soldiers after he reviewed the troops for the first time as commander.

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Our nation can never fully repay our debt to you, but we can give you our full support, and my administration will.

KATAYAMA: The president has said he would not ask for money until a complete review of the Pentagon is completed, and he's hinted that the defense budget would only grow slightly. Analysts do not expect a huge run-up in defense stocks this year.

JON KUTLER, QUARTERDECK INVESTMENT PARTNERS: Under a Bush administration, I think companies are more concerned about what programs will be cut in order to fund other ones.

KATAYAMA: Two areas many analysts bet Mr. Bush will fund are the $60 billion national missile defense system and electronics.

PIERRE CHAO, CS FIRST BOSTON: … that this administration is very focused on national missile defense and they're going to go ahead with that program. That's going to benefit players like Boeing, Raytheon, Lockheed Martin and TRW. The other area that's very clear that they're pushing ahead in is wanting to move on toward next generation technologies, and one of the underlying elements of all those technologies, a lot of defense electronics and information systems. That plays to a Raytheon or Northrup Grumman, an L3 Communications.

KATAYAMA: But Boeing and its partner, Textron, could lose out on their $30 billion V-22 Osprey, the aircraft that lifts off like a helicopter and flies like a plane.

ROBERT FRIEDMAN, STANDARD & POOR'S: The reason why I think this program is highly vulnerable for a total cancellation is that there were unfortunately four accidents in which there were several fatalities.

KATAYAMA: The Army's heavy tank, the Crusader, could get crushed because it was designed to combat antiquated Cold War strategies. The contractors behind that program, General Dynamics and a firm controlled by the Carlisle Group.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: Overall, analysts say it's hard to pick individual winners and losers. Given the rash of mergers, only half a dozen major players are left, and they now make an array of hardware. As one analyst put it, cutting one program to free up money for another is like taking money out of the left pocket and putting it into the right pocket.

Now, checking out how defense issues made out in today's trading, it was a mixed bag. Boeing delivered a strong showing to the upside, rising more than one. Northrup Grumman, General Dynamics and Raytheon all fell a fraction -- Willow.

BAY: All right, Fred, we'll keep an eye on those. Fred Katayama reporting.

Coming up next, it is bound to become a bestseller, the debut of the book of life. We'll talk with the man in charge of Celera Genomics version, Craig Venter, when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Shares of biotech youngster Celera Genomics Group jumped 15 percent today on the publication of its landmark and controversial map of the human genome, a cheat-sheet for human DNA.

Joining us from Washington to discuss this milestone, Craig Venter, president of Celera.

Craig, welcome to MONEYLINE.

CRAIG VENTER, PRESIDENT, CELERA GENOMICS: Thank you. How are you?

BAY: And I should say congratulations on a major historic scientific breakthrough. Of course, everybody on Wall Street is interested what the implications are for investors. Can you tell us, first of all, when we'll start to see drugs and treatments based on this map?

VENTER: Well, I think there's a number of things already in the works around the world based on earlier parts of genomics. But I think that what this new data tells us is the next steps are going to be a little bit more complicated and need new tools, new advanced analyses.

For example, we're setting up to do million protein sequences a day to really try and examine the next phase, because as you heard earlier today, we found far fewer genes than most people expected, which means the protein world and dissecting that is going to be a very key step for really developing new and advanced diagnostics and therapeutics.

BAY: So, Craig, let me ask you a question about that new discovery. So then are you suggesting that because there are 30,000 as opposed to the conventional wisdom of 100,000-or-so, it will be more complicated to devise treatments based on the map or less?

VENTER: It's going to actually be ironically more complicated. I think when people thought about having 100,000 or more genes, they thought about we would have one gene perhaps for every major trait, every major disease, every major biological function. So it was sort of linear thinking.

That's not how our physiology actually works. In fact, because there's fewer genes, we're going to see this larger expansion, much more regulation. It's going to be the control of the proteins, the protein-protein interactions. That's why we announced a few weeks ago this new interaction with the U.S. government, the Sandia Labs, Compaq Computer and Celera to try and build now the world's largest supercomputer to try and deconvolute all this complex information. We can't just do it a gene at a time anymore.

BAY: You make money by selling access to your database to allow companies to navigate the maps. So what does today's publication of the map mean for your revenue stream?

VENTER: I think it's going to get more people interested in understanding the next phases of biology. Having that map in front of them is going to be difficult for any scientist just to work on their one little spot, which they could do before without knowing all this information really existed. We're entering to this new holistic view of biology, where we have to look at all the genes, all the proteins in context. That's why we're alive and how we're alive. And for scientists to do that, they're going to have to have these new computer tools, the new high-end informatics, the ability to navigate through this information.

So we think it's going to drive this business forward much more rapidly.

BAY: Clearly a complex and historic discovery. Craig Venter of Celera Genomics, thanks for joining us.

VENTER: Thank you very much.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE, citizen Clinton on the speaking circuit. Will recent controversies put a crimp or give added life to the former president's drawing power?

VARNEY: Plus, with Alan Greenspan heading to Capitol Hill tomorrow, we'll ask our financial editor, Myron Kandel, what the markets will want to be hearing.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: His presence sparked a firestorm at his first major speaking engagement after leaving the White House. But while one Wall Street house says it now regrets hosting citizen Clinton, another major firm is sticking by its plan to pay top dollar to hear from the former president.

As Susan Lisovicz reports, the ongoing controversies surrounding Mr. Clinton may only enhance his worth on the lecture circuit.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PROTESTER: We want the people (UNINTELLIGIBLE), Mr. Clinton,

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Angry protesters referring to the latest controversy surrounding former President Bill Clinton outside his speaking engagement last week in Boca Raton. Even as a retired president, Mr. Clinton is still a lightning rod, and that's one reason he is so coveted on the speaking circuit.

But the Wall Street brokerage giant Morgan Stanley Dean Witter now says it regrets it paid the former president $100,000 to speak at that private conference in Boca Raton. Morgan's chairman and CEO Philip Purcell sent an e-mail to complaining customers that said "We made a mistake," that the firm "should have thought twice before the speaking invitation was extended, especially in light of Mr. Clinton's actions in leaving the White House." Credit Suisse First Boston is also reportedly paying the former president a six-figure fee for a speaking engagement later this month. And political experts say Mr. Clinton's continuing controversies won't diminish his opportunities in the future, either.

KARLYN BOWMAN, AMERICAN ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE: He'll have a lot of speaking engagements, and I think the one that he had at Morgan Stanley reflects the deep division of opinion that there is about this president. On the one hand, Americans approve very strongly of the job that he did as president. But on the other, they don't think he's honest and trustworthy.

LISOVICZ: A source knowledgeable with Morgan Stanley's conference says a small number of the dozens of clients who complained closed their accounts in protest. The source says Mr. Clinton's speaking performance, however, was widely regarded as wonderful by people in attendance.

Many veteran political experts say even if U.S. firms get cold feet about booking public citizen Bill Clinton in the near future, overseas businesses won't.

PHILIP FREIDMAN, POLITICAL CONSULTANT PJP ADVISORS: If he were to spend the next year touring foreign countries and giving speeches, there is no end to the amount of money that he could make and no end to the amount of applause that he would receive.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: And financial compensation is important to the former president after a long career as a public servant. CNN has learned that Mr. Clinton may now be setting his office in Harlem at a cost that would be less than half that of an office space he had been considering in midtown Manhattan -- Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, Susan Lisovicz reporting in New York. Thank you, Susan.

Now, Mr. Greenspan goes to Washington tomorrow, exactly one month and 10 days after shocking the financial world with a half point interest rate cut that came in between Federal Reserve meetings. Since then, however, the stock market's gone virtually nowhere.

Well, Mr. Greenspan speaks again tomorrow. What could be the market reaction? Could we start to see some kind of reaction tomorrow?

Here with his thoughts on that, Myron Kandel, financial editor. What is going to happen?

MYRON KANDEL, CNNFN FINANCIAL EDITOR: Well, Stuart, there's an old "Bing Cosby" song that said "Accentuate the positive, eliminate the negative." And I think that's the approach that Alan Greenspan is going to take tomorrow when he testifies to the Senate Banking Committee. Now, he really scared folks when he talked about the economy slowing to zero growth, right, and I think tomorrow he's talking not only to the senators on the committee but to the American consumer, because consumer confidence has really tumbled and Greenspan is very aware that consumer confidence is what -- is what is going to determine the course of the economy.

So I think he's going to look at the glass being half full rather than half empty as we get into the second half of this year, and I think that will be good for the stock market.

VARNEY: Do you think that tomorrow's speech, tomorrow's presentation is very, very important for starting the stock market off on a nice rally? Does it start tomorrow?

KANDEL: It started today, I think, and it gets accentuated tomorrow. I think we get above 11,000 for the first time since September at the close. And then, you know, once we're at in 11,000, 12,000 can't be far behind, Stuart.

VARNEY: And you said that many times.

KANDEL: Yeah.

VARNEY: Myron Kandel, thank you very much.

Up next, "Ahead of the Curve": some of what you need to know tonight before those markets open again tomorrow. Willow and I return in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Taking a look at some of what could move the markets tomorrow: All eyes will be on Washington as Alan Greenspan testifies before Congress on the state of the economy. Also watch for earnings from Applied Materials. Investors are looking for 63 cents per share plus quarterly reports from BP Amoco and Sycamore Networks.

And tomorrow, tune into "Ahead of the Curve": Hugh Johnson of First Albany will give his take on the economy ahead of Alan Greenspan's congressional testimony.

VARNEY: And finally tonight, one week after a strong debut performance, NBC's Saturday night XFL matchup was sacked by a remake of the popular classic "The Parent Trap." Viewers chose Walt Disney over the wrestling-meets-football offering by a wide margin. Ratings for the XFL fell 55 percent from last week's standout performance. That's according to Nielsen's overnight numbers.

In addition to losing viewers, the game also lost power. A generator in an NBC truck ran out of juice, cutting the signal of the game for most of the first quarter. The outage had nothing to do with the continuing power crisis in California.

BAY: Stuart, thank you. As a West Coast resident, I appreciate you pointing that out. VARNEY: You're welcome.

BAY: No more blackout jokes. That is MONEYLINE for this Monday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Good night from New York, and CROSSFIRE is next.

Khanna talks tech jobs across America with Prime Minister Tony Blair, Microsoft CEO Brad Smith at Web Summit2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:49ZLexisNexisRELEASE: Rep. Khanna talks tech jobs across America with Prime Minister Tony Blair, Microsoft CEO Brad Smith at Web Summit

Washington: Office of the MP Ro Khanna has issued the following news release:

This week, Rep. Ro Khanna, member of the House Oversight Committee and Congressional Representative for Silicon Valley, participated in the 2019 Web Summit in Lisbon, Portugal.

Rep. Khanna joined two of Web Summit’s robustly attended panels. The first, “None left behind: Making tech work for the many” was a fireside chat in conversation with former Prime Minister Tony Blair. The second, “Rebuilding trust in tech” was a conversation with Microsoft CEO Brad Smith. Khanna had several individual conversations with speakers while there, including former Prime Minister Tony Blair, who touted his efforts and innovation.

Rep. Khanna has traveled across rural America discussing opportunities to bring technology jobs into communities left behind and mapping out a future for the global economy. Rep. Khanna, in early 2020, will introduce a bill that will establish a grant program to build up tech-related schooling opportunities in the middle America – legislating his vision of transition to innovation-based economies. His plan entails a multibillion-dollar investment inspired by Morrill Act of 1862. Khanna has traveled to several economically distressed cities in Kentucky, West Virginia, Michigan, Ohio, Iowa, North Carolina and South Carolina. There, Rep. Khanna has partnered with local lawmakers to bring Silicon Valley representatives to meet with local businesses and universities to help form partnerships.

“The reality is that technology has enriched our lives in so many ways. In enhancing communication, enhancing the promise of medicine, enhancing the possibility of information. And yet that innovation and wealth has been concentrated in a few areas. And people in Silicon Valley are increasingly aware that many have been left out in rural America, in minority communities…. Our country will fall apart if we don’t integrate and provide those opportunities to these places that have been left out. Put simply, no child should be forced to leave their hometown to get a good job.

How are we going to create new jobs given the technology revolution? What are we going to do to make sure there’s not geographic inequality? What are we going to do to have thoughtful regulations, so democracy is enhanced, not undermined, based on these new platforms? So, my view is that the central question of governance is how are we going to have thoughtful economic policy, thoughtful regulation, to deal with the technology revolution, and that’s sorely missing in Congress.

Our politics are either about the restoration of the past, or an embrace of the future. At a very simple level, Donald Trump is saying ‘let’s go back to the past, let’s go back to the way life used to be,’ and if you believe, as I do, in a multi-cultural democracy… you have to convince people that technology and the future is going to be a force for good in their lives, not a force of disruption. That to me is the central challenge for modern politics,” said Rep. Khanna.

“It’s a great pleasure to be with Ro as well, whose work I admire greatly. The people being left behind are the people who don’t understand how technology is changing the world, who feel that the force of globalization is passing them by. The big challenge… is how do you get the changemakers and the policymakers together.

Today, the question of technology should run throughout government. My view is you need to reorder politics around handling this technological revolution…. the problem today is that you’ve got a real world revolution in this room, and you’ve got politics in the other room, and the question is how you put that together.

Technology is more than about Big Tech. It’s about all those companies that are being created now, that are doing new things, that are innovating. We need that energy to be in the political room as well . . . a lot of the time these guys want to be as far away from government as possible, I understand that. But it’s necessary for the politicians to understand the world in order that they make the right policy. And this dislocation between the revolution that’s happening on the ground and the political debate is worrying and it’s dangerous,” said Prime Minister Tony Blair.

urn:contentItem:5XRP-DM01-JD3N-51W8-00000-00Relief for banks as ACCC boss picks his battles2019-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:50ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 17Relief for banks as ACCC boss picks his battlesTICKY FULLERTON, THE INTERVIEW

It has been an anus horribilis for banking but in the latest inquiry into the sector the regulator has a message that should come as a relief for the big four.

On home loan pricing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission chief Rod Sims has ruled out forcing banks to lower the "loyalty tax" on long-term borrowers to be in line with the lower introductory rates used to attract new customers. Banks, already under pressure to explain why they have not passed on the full 75 basis point drop in the cash rate this year to borrowers, have been criticised for continuing to charge longstanding customers more.

"We are not saying in any way it is illegal; we are not in any way saying it is unethical," Sims says. "We are just saying to consumers, be aware if you stay with one entity, be it banking, be it energy, over time and you're not inquiring about better rates," Sims says.

His position is intended to signal a lack of competition in the mortgage market, but not a regulator that is hot to trot to intervene.

In electricity, in contrast, there has been heavy intervention in the market. "We could show you where a 45 per cent discount was a worse deal than zero discount, so it was completely confusing. The electricity industry let that get out of hand. I have a lot of evidence that they think so, too." Sims says that situation was not true of banking. "With banking we are saying to customers 'look, you might save a few basis points if you ring them up and say I'm thinking of moving'." Where Sims could well call for intervention is in his upcoming recommendations on water trading in the Murray-Darling Basin.

Australia leads the world with the most advanced market but in recent months, exacerbated by the drought, emotions have run hot, with accusations of unconscionable conduct by water hoarders as prices have skyrocketed. The ACCC spent November consulting throughout the Murray-Darling basin. "I guess the issue is: has it got more sophisticated than the nature of the market can handle?" Sims asks.

He contrasts the water market with the foreign exchange market, where he says an arbitrage play would typically be a sign that the market is working well. "Pardon the pun - the water market is pretty illiquid, because it is really 40 markets connected by rivers when they flow or don't flow. The question we have to address is, is it too thin a market to cater for how it now works?" Sims is unmoved by the politics. "We are too early into this to indicate what we might recommend to government, but I don't think we will be constrained by sovereign risk issues. Given how we understand how this market works, we will try to solve what is the right way it should work." Sims finishes the year delighted, he says, with the government's response to his digital platforms review. He bats off any criticism that his central recommendation - a "voluntary" code between the likes of Google and Facebook and traditional media - will be ineffective, given the form of big tech.

"I think there's been a misunderstanding here. The word voluntary underplays that it will be enforceable and there's an imperative to get something done because there is a big stick at the end of it." That big stick is the threat of a government-mandated code by next November if the carve-up of the rivers of gold is not sorted by then.

Sims has healthy doubts about digital. He famously would not have an Amazon Alexa at home, he mistrusts Google's assurances on Fitbit data as part of its $2.1bn takeover, and he has taken Google to court this year over alleged misleading of customers on the treatment of their location data. By the release of the draft report in July, Sims had five in-depth investigations running into big tech.

Sims is looking to shift the dial in consumer protection, with a far greater weight on fairness that will alarm business. Sims argues that judges have understandably interpreted unconscionable conduct narrowly, at a time when society wants to deal with what is unfair.

"Let's say on a digital platform that a scam is being run that Facebook knows about and they don't do anything to take it down. Now is that unconscionable? No, it would not amount to unconscionable. Is it unfair? Well, people are suffering detriment. Why don't you take it down?

"If what we're worried about is customers being treated unfairly, my view is, don't bring in a whole lot of laws. I worry we're trying to legislate for particular things when, if there's behaviour we don't want, just make that illegal. If what we're trying to do is stamp out unfairness in the marketplace, why don't we just say so?" Any move to a threshold of fairness would be seen as a dramatic change in business and could lead to the same sort of rearguard action as the controversial Section 46 "effects" test on market power. "Well that was irrational as well," Sims says. "I understand that would be the reaction from many, but I don't think it is. I don't think business does itself any favours by opposing everything that comes along. My message to them is, if you can see the wider benefit, just endorse it even though it might not be in your particular interest, because then you have more credibility for opposing things when there are really things that should not happen." One of the most contentious actions under way is the regulator's criminal cartel conduct case against ANZ, Citi and Deutsche on alleged syndicate behaviour. Under scrutiny is the grant-ing of immunity to JPMorgan, whose executives, along with ACCC personnel, are being grilled. "Obviously with cartels you are talking about covert behaviour where it is hard to work out what is going on. So every competition regulator around the world that we would identify with has these immunity programs." Whatever the regulator achieves, he can be sure of one thing: more complaints about petrol. Why is there no big stick for petrol pricing? "Good question," Sims grins. "It is the dominant criticism, every time we announce something there is always a Twitter feed of 'well that's hopeless - what are you doing about petrol?'"" Sims says people, including some members of parliament, misunderstand the law. "People understandably say 'I saw signs for $1.20 three days ago and now it's $1.50. The world oil price hasn't gone up, I'm getting ripped off, what's the ACCC doing about it?' "Well firstly, that form of ripping off is not illegal. When the price is at the bottom of the cycle, it is an unusually good deal and when it is at the top of the cycle, it is a lousy deal, so if you average it through the year, are petrol prices too high?

"You can quibble about 1c or 2c, 3c, but that is all you're talking about. You are not getting ripped off by 30c. You are if you buy at the top of the cycle and we have our website to help people avoid that."Ticky Fullerton is Sky News Business Editor and co-anchor of Business Weekend, Sundays at 11am on Sky News Australia.

urn:contentItem:51M1-50Y1-JCV1-Y1W8-00000-00Religare maintains `Hold` on Infosys Technologies2010-12-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:50ZLexisNexisReligare maintains `Hold` on Infosys Technologies

http://www.myiris.com/IndexServer/storyImages/2010/12/02/20101202_596169_1.png   http://www.myiris.com/IndexServer/logoImages/INFTECHN_1.gif Religare Capital has recommended `Hold` on Infosys Technologies with a price target of Rs 3,200 as against the current market price (CMP) of Rs 3,052 in its report dated Dec. 02, 2010. The broking house gave the following rationale:

Near-term demand traction intact: While the management was comfortable on the near-term demand strength, the company highlighted that visibility on actual spending is limited. This is driven by the continued uncertainty in the macro environment which, in our view, also reflects in the divergent performance of some big tech names such as Cisco. This year, IT budgets are likely to be used up completely unlike in CY09 which saw only 70-75% of the budgeted amount being spent. Further, CY10 volumes have not only benefited from underinvestment in the previous years leading to some pent up demand, but have also seen increased spending related to regulatory/compliance issues. While select accounts have seen some higher pricing, on a blended basis, pricing remains stable.

Offshoring gaining traction: Europe contributes 22% of Infosys` total revenues and the management indicated that exposure to the troubled European nations is limited as UK/Germany/France is the key markets for Infosys. Also, its exposure to public and government projects in these markets is limited. The management noted that demand is cost-structure driven, as certain verticals such as retail are under an increasing pressure to optimise costs. This is also notably leading to greater push for Offshoring in Europe.

Outlook: While IT budgets are likely to be finalised by Jan-Feb `10, early discussions suggest that budgets could be flattish. There has been some pick-up in discretionary spends and verticals such as manufacturing and retail are witnessing improved spends. In the telecom space, OEM spends are still under check but specific service providers are likely to see better spends. Further as per the management, tech spends are likely to be driven by continued focus of corporates towards enhancing their competitiveness, regulatory compliance and M&A given high cash balances with large companies.

urn:contentItem:5WTD-R121-DY0W-447B-00000-00Remarks at a Presidential Social Media Summit2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:50ZLexisNexisPg. 1Remarks at a Presidential Social Media SummitDonald J TrumpWashingtonFULL TEXT

Administration of Donald J. Trump, 2019

July 11, 2019

The President. Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. Please sit down.

I want to thank you all for being here, very special day, very important day. Many of you are friends, and many of you are friends that I don't know what you look like, but I know what you sound like-[laughter]-which, I guess, is probably more important. Right?

But I want to thank you. And it's a terrific day to be together. And if you look, you're in a very famous place. We all work very hard. And I don't know if you call it "influence," I don't know if you call it "power," but whatever it is, we're in the White House. And we're going to stay in the White, and we're going to get our agenda done and completed beautifully. Hey, you.

So I'm thrilled to welcome you here. And we're all working very hard. And I don't know if you know, but we just did 27,000 on the Dow. That's the highest in history. We're up a couple of hundred points today-the highest in history-for those of you that like the stock market.

But the stock market means jobs. I view it as jobs, and I view it as 401(k)s. A lot of people say, "Oh, the rich people are getting rich." But if you look at the numbers, the greatest impact, proportionately, is blue-collar workers in what's happened, in this miracle that's happening.

And people with 401(k)s, they're up 72 percent and 67 percent. And the wife or the husband-whoever is responsible-the other one says: "You're a genius. You're a great financial investor." [Laughter] "Darling, you're up 77 percent this year." [Laughter]

So a lot of good things happened. A lot of people are happy. And I think, really, everybody is happy; some people just aren't willing to admit it. Does that make sense? [Laughter]

So this is a historic day. Never before have so many online journalists and influencers-and that's exactly what you are; you're journalists, and you're influencers-come together in this building to discuss the future of social media. Each of you is fulfilling a vital role in our Nation. You're challenging the media gatekeepers and the corporate censors to bring the facts straight to the American people. And that's what you're doing: You're going right to the people.

Possibly, we wouldn't be here right now. I asked somebody: "What do you think I'd do without social media? Would I be here?" Because I said, "I think so." [Laughter] But they weren't so sure. [Laughter] I have to say that; you know that. I'm not sure I believe that, but I have to say it.

But you communicate directly with our citizens without having to go through the fake-news filter. It's very simple. Together, you reach more people than any television broadcast network by far, not even close.

We're delighted to be joined at this summit by someone you know very well: our Senior Adviser for Digital Strategy and somebody that's been working for me for a long time, for many years, Dan Scavino. Where is Dan? Stand up. Come here. Great job.

So, long before we were even doing this, he was at a club-running a club and other businesses. And he was okay at doing it. [Laughter] Not the greatest. I wouldn't say the greatest. [Laughter] But you know what he was great at? He was always looking at his computer screen. I said, "That guy is incredible."

So, right at the beginning, I said, "That's the man." And there was nobody better at that. And I think Hillary had 28 people, and I had Dan. [Laughter] Right? It's true. I had my Dan. And he works about 28 hours a day, and he works very hard. But he doesn't work-I mean, he loves it. He loves it. And his imagination and, really, working with all of you and many of you, he'll come up with ideas, and you'll come up with ideas. And he'll run into my office. He said, "You've got to see this."

And a lot of times, I'll go out, and I'll spend a lot of money on a concept. I'll say: "Here's a concept. Come up with this." And we'll hire these companies, and they want a lot of money. And they come back-it just happened the other day, right? I said: "That's terrible. These guys have no talent." [Laughter] The people that have the talent are the people that we deal with. And it's true.

And some of you are extraordinary. I can't say everybody, but-[laughter]. No, but some of you are extraordinary. The crap you think of is unbelievable. [Laughter] It's true. Unbelievable.

So I'm going to go back to the basics of Washington. I'm going to introduce some of my Secretaries. Steve Mnuchin. Steve? Where's Steve? Steve has done a fantastic job. Wilbur Ross. Wilbur? We have a meeting in a little while, on the census and citizenship. Can you believe: "Are you a citizen of the United States of America?" "Sir, you can't ask that question." [Laughter] "Why?" "Because the Court said you can't."

We have three very unfriendly courts. They fight us all the way. The judges don't like us too much, I guess. But think of that, Herman. Think of that question: "Are you a citizen?"

We spend-this is another thing that's so crazy: $20 billion on a census-$20 billion. They spend $20 billion. I said, "20 billion what?" [Laughter] Twenty billion dollars on a census.

They go through houses-they go up, they ring doorbells, they talk to people. "How many toilets do they have?" "How many desks do they have?" "How many beds?" "What's their roof made of?" [Laughter] The only thing we can't ask is, "Are you a citizen of the United States?" [Laughter] No, is this the craziest thing? Twenty billion. Pretty amazing. Pretty amazing, Charlie.

Also, David Bernhardt, great job you're doing-Interiors. He's the largest landlord in the United States. When my friends tell me how big they are, they-"I just bought another building." Big deal, Kevin, right? They bought another building. Then, I look at David Bernhardt; he controls half of the United States. [Laughter] Department of Interiors. There's a lot of land-a lot of beautiful land-that we're taking good care of, David. Right?

Acting Director Russ Vought. Russ, thank you. Great job. We're working on our budget.

Along with some of the great Members of Congress and a wonderful friend of mine who's my leader, right? He's my leader. I tell him that to his face because it makes him feel good. I don't know if I believe that, Marsha. [Laughter] But, Kevin-stand up, Kevin. Kevin McCarthy, everybody.

Senator Marsha Blackburn of the great State of Tennessee. We campaigned together. And she did-we can say it now: She ran against the most popular Democrat in the last 50 years. He really was great. A good man, right? And Governor for quite a long time, 8 years. And she just didn't stop.

Senator Marsha Wedgeworth Blackburn. I beat him by 12 points.

The President. Twelve points. She was down by 10, and she won by 12. That's right. She was down by 10, and she won by 12. And she wouldn't stop. They just-every day, "Where is she?" "She's here. She's there." Fantastic job you did. We're proud of you.

Sen. Blackburn. Thank you-[inaudible].

The President. Well, thank you, honey. That's great. It was just-honestly, working with people that know what they're doing, it's fun. That was fun. And you know what you're doing.

Representative Dan Crenshaw, who is very good at this, by the way, Dan. Very good at this. Really good. Thank you. It's great to have you in the party. And you have more courage than I do, Dan. Okay? That courage of yours is incredible. Thank you very much. Great job.

A friend of mine and a wonderful person and somebody that has, I don't know, a pretty unlimited future, I'd say-I hear a lot of very positive things-Liz Cheney. Liz, thank you. Thank you.

And you know, I pardoned somebody named Scooter Libby. A lot of you don't know who Scooter Libby is. Scooter Libby is a man that got treated very unfairly. And Liz was right on the forefront of that one. And I said, "What do you think, Liz?" And you said: "Absolutely. He deserves it." And it's been a very popular pardon. He was treated very, very brutally and unfairly. So thank you for that, for that help.

Matt Gaetz. Where's Matt? Where's Matt? Stand up, Matt. Boy, a great defender. He gets on television, and he's like-it doesn't stop. [Laughter] And he's smart, and he's good, and he loves Florida, and he loves his people, and he's a hard worker. And, Matt, thank you very much. I really appreciate it very much.

And Mike Johnson. Mike, thank you. Great job, Mike.

And I want to thank a man who I said, a long time ago, when we said, "Let's do it"-because Josh Hawley is special. He is somebody that-I said, "Josh, you've got to run." "Well, I don't know." You know, he had a good setup-pretty well, right? You weren't going anywhere. He could do whatever he wanted in his great State.

And I said, "I'm telling you, you can do it." And she turned out-she's a tough candidate. Whether you like her or you don't like her, she's tough. Right? And by the end of that, that was incredible. That was a hell of a race, and he won. And he's young, and he's brilliant. And I'm going to ask him to come up and say a few words, if you don't mind, about what we're doing. And come on up right now. I think it would be a good time, right?

Senator Joshua D. Hawley. Thank you. Well, first of all, can we just give another round of applause to the President of the United States for his leadership on this issue? You know, the media says-the establishment media, the fake media-they say: "Oh, there's no censorship in social media. That's all made up. That's all fake." You and I know that that's not true. You and I know the truth is that the social media giants would love to shut us down. They would love to shut us up. They would love to shut him up more than anything else. And we can't let them. And that's why we need to step up now.

And I think we need to say to them, "Here's the deal." Google, Facebook, Twitter-they've gotten these special deals from Government. They've gotten a special giveaway from Government. They're treated unlike anybody else. If they want to keep their special deal, here's the bargain: They have to quit discriminating against conservatives. Do you agree with that? No more! No more discrimination. It's that simple. That's all we're asking for.

They ought to abide by the same principles of free speech and the First Amendment that this country embraces, that we love and call our own. But they're not using that brilliance, and they're not using what we gave them fairly. And they have to do that.

And we don't want to stifle anything. We certainly don't want to stifle free speech, but that's no longer free speech. See, I don't think that the mainstream media is free speech either, because it's so crooked. It's so dishonest.

So, to me, free speech is not when you see something good, and then you purposely write bad. To me, that's very dangerous speech, and you become angry at it. But that's not free speech. Somebody came to my office-and I won't say who, but a very big person-and I said, "Okay, you don't like the term 'fake news'"-which I think I get credit for, but I'm sure that, if I said I get credit, they'll say, "Thirteen years ago, somebody came up with the terms 'fake.'" [Laughter] I think I'd get credit. I'd be very proud to take it. But I think I'd get credit.

Now, by the way, the worst fakers of all are using "fake news." I saw the other day on CNN-total fakes-I see on CNN-they go, "Fake-news media has reported"-no, no, they're fake-news media. [Laughter] They've turned it around. They've turned it around.

So I'm not going to allow-and Josh and all of us, we're not just going to allow it to happen like this. We're not going to be silenced.

Two months ago, we created a new White House tool to report social media bias, censorship, and discrimination. We saw you folks being taken off, and we fought on all of you. And many of you are back now. But many of the names-I won't mention your names-but some of you were taken off for absolutely no reason.

I mean, in all fairness, some of you I could almost understand. [Laughter] I mean, some of you guys are out there. [Laughter] But even you should have a voice. [Laughter] But some of you-no, some of you deserve-[applause]-some of you. I mean, it's genius, but it's bad. [Laughter]

But they take off people that are-you know, that you wouldn't believe. And we received over 16,000 responses just in a tiny little period of time talking about this subject.

Based on the feedback that we're hearing from you, I'm announcing that we will ask representatives of the major social media platforms to join me at the White House over the next month, have a big meeting and a real conversation. We want-might want to invite some of you. I know, Josh, we're going to have you and some of the Senators.

And it's amazing how the Senators-including Democrats, in all fairness-which is probably because they know it can turn on them also. It can turn very quickly. But they want to come. So we'll let you know the date, okay?

And today I'm directing my administration to explore all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech and the free speech rights of all Americans. That's you people in this room and a lot of people out there. There are a lot of people.

We hope to see transparency, more accountability, and more freedom. That's on both sides. This is not-I am not speaking for our side, assuming we're all-I don't even know if you're on our side. You could be some of the most liberal people in the world in this audience, and that's okay. I don't care. But we're talking about for everybody. Big tech must not censor the voices of the American people.

To all of the social media influencers here today-a lot of-you have a lot of power, and you have a lot of strength. And you know, you have to use it wisely. Many of you do, but you have to. I want to thank you once again for being here. You're very special people. You're very brilliant people, in so many cases. I look around the room, I mean, I see people that really have almost found a new life over the last short period of time with this new technology. But this new technology is so powerful and so important, and it has to be used fairly. It has to be used fairly.

So thank you all for being here. It's a great honor, tremendous honor.

We're going to take a few questions, I think. And then, I'll head out. And you're going to actually come-if you want, you can come to the great Rose Garden. You can stand in the rain with me. We're going to talk a little bit about the fact that we're not allowed to ask for whether or not somebody is a citizen on the census form. And I think we have a solution that will be very good for a lot of people, really good.

[The event continued with a question-and-answer session, and no transcript was provided.]

NOTE: The President spoke at 3:51 p.m. in the East Room at the White House. In his remarks, he referred to 2016 Democratic Presidential nominee Rodham Clinton; businessman and commentator Herman Cain; Charlie Kirk, founder and executive director, Turning Point USA; Acting Director of the Office of Management and Budget Russell T. Vought; former Gov. Phil Bredesen of Tennessee; Reps. Elizabeth L. Cheney, Matthew L. Gaetz, and J. Michael Johnson; former Sen. Claire C. McCaskill; former Chief of Staff to the Vice President I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby; Mark Burnett, chairman, MGM Worldwide Television Group; actor James Woods; Counselor to the President Kellyanne Conway; former Gov. Arnold A. Schwarzenegger of California; social media personalities Lynette "Diamond" Hardaway and Rochelle "Silk" Richardson; musician Joy Villa; Jen Gennai, head of responsible innovation, Google, Inc.; James O'Keefe, founder and president, Project Veritas; former Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Jr.; Sens. Elizabeth A. Warren and Charles E. Schumer; Kimberly Guilfoyle, former cohost, Fox News's "The Five" program; Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome H. Powell; Hayden Williams, director of campus strategy, Leadership Institute; and Jack Dorsey, chief executive officer, Twitter.
